characters: NO ONE CAN KICK MY ASS BETTER
WE DISSOLVE THROUGH THE GLASS TO LATER IN THE GAME
ARE YOU SURE WHAT'S THE FINAL
I WILL, YOU DON'T SHIT ABOUT
THE MANDIKES SLAUGHTER OF THE KIKUYUS
CONOR AND TICKY OUTSIDE THE BAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a windy march night in Chicago as CONOR O'NEILL climbs the steps of St. John's church. He pauses at the top of the stairs to take a long pull off a bottle in a brown bag. He enters the dark church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR pours himself into the last pew and unhooks the bow-tie of his rented tux. He's more exhausted than any 29 year old needs to be. A PRIEST leaving the church spots Conor and approaches him. The PRIEST is wearing street clothes and carries his formal work clothes an a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: I gotta lock up son. CONOR nods in understanding while not breaking his drunken stare. The PRIEST senses CONOR's unhappiness. PRIEST (cont'd) You looking for faith? Forgiveness? CONOR gets up to leave. He looks at the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Milwaukee to beat the spread. CONOR leaves the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR bolster's his courage by finishing the bagged pint and tossing it in the alley. He exhales before entering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The typical Irish bar is alive with the sounds and smells of basketball and stale beer. Heads turn when they see CONOR enter, obviously an unwelcome regular. The bartender grabs CONOR by the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Conor are you nuts? CONOR pulls free and grabs a bowl of nuts off the bar. CONOR flings the nuts on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: These are nuts. CONOR stumbles into a bar patron who shoves him out of the way. It's clear in the light that CONOR is drunk and probably has been all day. The BARTENDER has caught up to him.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Duffy's here, you better have his money.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I got it. The BARTENDER looks incredulously at CONOR who fesses up. CONOR (cont'd) I'm gonna have it, what's the score?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You're into Duffy for at least 5 grand, who gave you an account?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I laid 6 grand with Barber, to get me even. CONOR has locked his drunken eyes on the TV above the bar that barks out the Bulls game.

dialogues.speaker: BAR FLY
dialogues.text: Bulls by 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got Milwaukee gettin' eleven.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Two minutes to go.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah baby, keep the clock runnin'. A young guy wearing an identical tux appears next to CONOR. This is JIIMMY. Behind him are two BRIDE'S MAIDS in poofy peach satin gowns.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I can't believe you, you split Mikey's wedding to come to Duffy's. CONOR doesn't even acknowledge his fellow groomsman as he addresses the TV.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Stop! What are they fouling him for?! JIMMY shakes his head but stays with CONOR. CONOR is locked on the TV. CONOR (cont'd) C'mon there's only a minute left it's over.

dialogues.speaker: BAR FLY
dialogues.text: Jordan's hit 16 free throws in a row. That's 17.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Bulls by nine, hang on. Just hang on. DUFFY is a big burly Irish guy who comes out of a back office lead by the BARTENDER who obviously tipped him off about CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't bet the Barber with my money? Right O'Neill? You're not that stupid.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Shut up Duffy, in 18 seconds you'll have your money. They all study the screen. Jordan steals the ball and attempts to run the court but is tackled by Ray Allen. CONOR (cont'd) That's okay even if he makes them both, it's eleven. I push. I'm even.

dialogues.speaker: BAR FLY
dialogues.text: Flagrant foul, he shoots one for that first. CONOR throws his hands in the air and hollers his frustration.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: That's bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: BAR FLY
dialogues.text: That's 18 in a row. We watch the screen now as Jordan is smiling, taunting the Milwaukee Bucks as he stands on the line. Six seconds left with two free throws to go and the Bulls up 10. JORDAN launches the shot, it hits the front of the rim, hops over it, hits the back board and falls through the hoop. The ugliest free throw in history. CONOR nearly jumps out of his skin.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: How the hell did that fall?!  JORDAN laughs at his own luck and resets for his last attempt. He sets, throws, nothing but net. BULLS by 12, the Bucks in-bound the ball and immediately begin shaking hands as they let the last couple of seconds tick off the clock. CONOR has gone silent as he instinctively starts drinking someone else's scotch off the bar. CONOR gets shoved by the man he stole the drink from. DUFFY begins to approach him. CONOR makes his way towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Grab him! CONOR rushes out the door and into the street. He takes off but a side door opens and the BARTENDER grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Get off a me. The BARTENDER squeezes him with his forearm. CONOR (cont'd) That's a hairy arm, I bet you shave your ass. The BARTENDER punches CONOR in the head with his free hand. CONOR wobbles from the blow but the BARTENDER keeps him standing. The bar has emptied to the street as DUFFY approaches CONOR. DUFFY clocks CONOR blind side and he drops like a rag doll from the grip of the BARTENDER.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: I'm first O'Neill, you pay me first. The crowd is silent as they watch the drunk and now injured CONOR attempt to regain his feet. It's like watching a two year old walk as CONOR takes a stumbly step before standing upright. He addresses the assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna beat my ass? CONOR stumbles towards a parked car, he violently punches his hand through the driver side window. The crowd is motionless as he again turns to them, blood pouring from his hand. He howls now...

dialogues.speaker: THAN I CAN
dialogues.text: CONOR careens towards the crowd wildly waving his bloody hand. He suddenly changes course and lowers his head, ramming it through the window of Duffy's bar. To the gallery's surprise, CONOR rises unsteadily and makes a lame lunge at the crowd before falling almost face first an the pavement. JIMMY rushes to him and the crowd seems to disperse. DUFFY and the BARTENDER stand over CONOR's body. We hear the sound of sirens growing closer as we fade out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The classic jail sound of metal hitting metal wakes CONOR who's been asleep sitting on the floor. He lifts his head from his knees and stares out at a familiar voice.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Conor, it's Ticky. IT'S

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: TICKY is a thirty-some year old ticket scalper who wears a quilted BULL's jacket and a BULL's National Champs painter's cap backwards.  A COP leads CONOR from his small holding cell. We now see that the blood stains on the raffle of his rented tux shirt match the makeshift bandage on his right hand. The large square bandaid on his forehead doesn't quite cover the scrape that's now marked with dark purple blood crust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COP pulls CONOR by the handcuffs to a large wooden bench in the lobby. TICKY watches as the COP routinely cuffs CONOR to the iron arm of the bench. CONOR offers in a weak voice...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Ticky, did you call my sister? TICKY leans close to CONOR in an effort to hear him. CONOR (cont'd) Did you call my sister?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Damn, you got zactly's breath?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Zactly's breath?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Your breath smells zactly like your ass. Damn, that's nasty.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Where's my sister?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: She's comin' to get you, but came for the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Which ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got two pair on the floor for the Bulls Rockets.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah but you're not in on those remember? I'm gonna hawk those myself, the game's not till 7.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: It's 5.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Just tell me where they are.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Shit, under the uh...religious statue on my dresser. TICKY's already leaving. CONOR (cont'd) Wait, Ticky I want 1200, Ticky! CONOR slumps against the wall, he pulls his head back in pain. We hear the sound of pointy heels clicking pertly an the ground. KERRY O'NEILL appears with her older fiancée FRANK TORTORICI. KERRY is 23 going on 40 with over done nails and jewelry. FRANK is 40 going on 60 with a nebulous connection to the construction business in urban Chicago. KERRY stares disapprovingly at her older brother

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: This is gonna cost Frank eight hundred and fifty dollars. (commanding Frank)  Frankie go pay the guy. FRANK jumps to obey KERRY's command.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Frank, I really-

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: This is the last time, you're scarin' me Conor. You're just like Dad it breaks my heart -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm not just like Dad!

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah?! Duffy called the house today and said you smashed up his bar sounds like dad to me!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Kerry -

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: How many tickets you gonna scalp to pay for that? Huh? You'll be scalping tickets for Barney and Friends on ice, I swear to God. KERRY starts walking away as the COP returns with FRANK to uncuff CONOR from the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see CONOR get out of FRANK's late model Buick and make his way up the stoop of an apartment building in Rogers Park. An extremely modest neighborhood that sets the border between the exquisite Gold Coast and the ghetto ghost town of the Cabrini Green housing projects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the shower running as we pan the small one bedroom apartment. A cheap lamp lights the statue of Mary Magdalen standing an the desk. An old wooden color console TV playing a basketball game lights the rest of the cluttered room. A double mattress on the floor is at home with the sneakers and other clothes that take up most of the walking space. A Julius Erving poster inhabits the otherwise sparse walls. It appears as though CONOR has lived here a long time with no attempts to decorate. The shower stops and we can now hear the sound of the TV playing a post game show. CONOR steps from the bathroom wearing a CUBS beach towel around his waist, obviously a give away from a promotional day at Wrigley. CONOR holds a hand towel to the cut on his forehead. The doorbell rings. CONOR is immediately wary, he grabs an aluminum softball bat and steps to the side of the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: It's Ticky, let me in. CONOR tosses the bat silently on the bed and begins unlocking the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Ticky, thank God, I really need that money... (as he opens the door) How much did you get for the tickets? CONOR opens the door to see TICKY get shoved aside by TwO GUYS. They immediately pin the toweled CONOR against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Neill, you remember me?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: They grabbed me outside the United Center-

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Barber's son.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: O'Neill, do you even remember making that call from Michael Pistone's wedding?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Get off a me.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: You spoke to me, and you said "It's O'Neill number 55 what's my limit?" I checked number 55 and I saw it had a six grand limit. CONOR shoves him but BARBER'S SON slams against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: I took your six grand on Milwaukee and it went down so I asked my dad about O'Neill on account 55 and he said the guy on that account died six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Tell the Barber-

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: You bet six grand on your dead father's account, and now you owe my very alive, very pissed off father 6600. him harder BARBER'S SON pins him further up the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon let me down I'm ina towel would you relax, I'm not goin' anywhere. BARBER'S SON lets him down but stands in his face. CONOR (cont'd) I'm gonna pay him, Ticky give him the 1200 from tonight and well go from there. TICKY looks to CONOR with an apologetic smile.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I rolled it on the Bulls tonight on my own number with Duffy.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I was gonna give 'ya the 2400 when it covered.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: Bulls won by three, spread was five, same old stories with you guys, if this, if that...forget it, I need some money.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Here I'll give you everything I got. CONOR pulls a crinkled hand of bills from his rented tux pants. The other thug, GINO, counts it.

dialogues.speaker: GINO
dialogues.text: 47 dollars. BARBER'S SON now grabs the bat and swings it against the wall. It makes an easy gash, he continues talking as if nothing just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what to do?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Either I'll get a loan and pay someone else the juice every week or you can put me on a payment and I'll pay you the juice, you tell me. BARBER's son thinks it over, he grabs the bills from the other THUG.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: You owe 6600, you pay me...5700 a week until I say stop.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous, 400. BARBER'S SON silently accepts his counter offer and then points the bat at him.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: Bring it to the barber shop, but don't make me come back up here. I'm serious, please don't make me come back here. The BARBER'S SON'S plea seems soft but deadly serious. They leave. TICKY turns to CONOR who waves his hands making him leave with out saying a word. CONOR shuts and locks his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The business district teems with the foot traffic of well dressed professionals. CONOR sifts through this stream in casual clothes and a fishing hat properly angled to cover the bandaged gash on his forehead. He pauses to look up the face of the tall bank building he's about to enter. He goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR looks a bit out of place in the reception area of this white collar money circus. A CUTE RECEPTIONIST blushes for him as he approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm Conor O'Neill, I have a 11:30 with James Devlin.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Does he know what it's regarding?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: The purchase of Wrigley field and the firing of sassy receptionists who wear aerobic sneakers to work and think that guys in fishing hats are sexy but dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (completely thrown) Just a minute. (into headset) Mr. O'Neill is here for his 11:30 with Mr. Devlin. Ok, yes. (to Conor) Right down that corridor Mr. O'Neill. CONOR walks in the direction her hand is pointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We recognize the man behind the desk as JIMMY, the other groomsman in a tux at Duffy's bar. He now wears a serious, conservative business suit complete with suspenders. JIMMY leaves CONOR standing in the doorway off his glass walled office. CONOR feels self-conscious with his fishing hat and bandages. JIMMY gets off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Neill, on time for your 11:30, uncommon for you, it must be important.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, Jimmy, I'm sorry about the other night after the wedding... CONOR waits for JIMMY to jump in, he doesn't. CONOR (cont'd) At Duffy's y'know, I was slightly over-served and uh... JIMMY continues to smile smugly at CONOR who we begin to feel sweating. CONOR (cont'd) I wanted to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Is that why you came down here?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No, I mean yes, it is but I also came because of what happened.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You know the bet I had went down, and I busted up Duffy's bar a little and I uh kinda dug myself a big hole.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I would imagine.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So what d'ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what? CONOR sighs and shifts his feet, he is burning in shame.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Can you help me out?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Help you with what?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Jimmy, you know why I came down here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I need to hear you say it so I get it loud and clean CONOR digs deep and lays out what's left of his pride.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Can you lend me 12 grand? JIMMY lets the moment resonate.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You need to bury your father again?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Did you dig the guy up?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You're sick.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Me?! Five months ago you're in here cryin' for 5 grand to bury your old man. I talked to Scott Mahoney at Mikey's  wedding seems he also lent you 5 grand to bury the guy.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm gonna pay Mahoney back -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I don't care how much you owe Mahoney -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: It's just right now I'm really up against it with Duffy and the Barber -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: And I really don't give a shit how much you owe the bookies - CONOR starts out. JIMMY (cont'd) Wait, come back in. CONOR does. JIMMY (cont'd) Close the door. What's with you? You're the only one left at Duffy's. I'm gone, Mikey's gone, Mahoney. What are you doin'? Hangin' around with Ticky Tobin scalpin' tickets and bettin' games? Selfish, I can't believe I'm gonna do this for you. This is the last time. JIMMY starts writing a check.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (relieved) I'm done betting and I swear I'm gonna pay you back-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not, you never do, so don't even say it. You never follow through on anything.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who said that? Mahoney? JIMMY hands him a check, CONOR snatches it and studies the amount. CONOR has

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: This might actually help you.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: This is only 500 bucks.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I know, you're gonna coach a kids baseball team with me.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Jimmy you don't understand how serious my situation is -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna pay you 500 a week for the next 10 weeks, that's week one. no choice in the matter.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Jimmy I ain't good with kids.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I do this to give something back to the community. You don't wanna do it, gimme the check back. CONOR stands in the doorway, he's got no choice.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I'll see you at the field tomorrow, 3:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it? JIMMY's now rushing him out.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That field on 1150 Carson, 3:30. CONOR's face goes blank.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: That's really South on Carson are you sure it's-

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, 1150 Carson it's behind the Oscar Meyer plant. JIMMY pushes him out the door, CONOR talks through the glass wall.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No, the only thing behind the Oscar Meyer plant is Cabrini Green. The projects. JIMMY has waved his last goodbye with a smile as he's jumped on a phone call. JIMMY pulls the blinds and CONOR looks around to see the office smiling at him. He realizes now that 500 a week might be a billion dollars short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARSON FIELD is surrounded by the ugly buildings of the failing Cabrini housing projects. The neighborhood looks and feels as dangerous as it is. A ghost town of unemployment, people stay off the streets day or night. CONOR makes his way across the beaten grass of Cabrini Baseball field. He wears an old Cubs hat as the only modification from his typical outfit that consists of work pants and black shoes.  It's still cool in March so his leather coat is appropriate. He sees a group of kids near a worn back stop with a wooden set of bleachers nearby. CONOR makes his way to the group but opts for a spot on the bleachers when he doesn't see JIMMY. We get a closer look at the kids who all appear to be between 9 and 12. There's probably 7 kids total who are all actively doing something counter productive. A little kid chases a tall skinny kid. Another kid just listens to a walkman as he slowly rocks, while another kid holds court with a tattered blue aluminum bat. Suddenly a 1998 BMW pulls up behind the backstop, the kids run to surround it. It's JIMMY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our 7 kids are awed with JIMMY's car. JIMMY tries to "shoo" them away in attempts to prevent little fingerprints on what is a glass-like finish to the car. We also see a woman in the passenger seat, it's the CUTE RECEPTIONIST from Morgan Stanley. ALONZO, the kid with the blue bat, leans in the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Check out coach Jimmy's whip, damn this shit is pimped.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Please guys, don't touch the car, it's new. Please you'll ruin the wax. A heavy set kid named CALVERT shoves ALONZO out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Yo coach Jimmy, here's my extra inhaler. CALVERT begins to hand JIMMY a collection of stuff.  CALVERT (cont'd) Here's my sugar babies for when my blood needs sugar, my mama says I do better when my blood's got sugar and -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Calvert Jefferson Tibbs, coach Jimmy but -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Everybody listen! The kids get quiet as JIMMY speaks. JIMMY (cont'd) The guy behind you is Coach Conor, he's taking over the day to day operations. CONOR steps closer when he hears his name.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What? The tall thin kid pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: That bummy guy's coach?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Coach Conor I just stopped by to give you the equipment. JIMMY pushes a button and the trunk pops open. The kids scramble for the worn army bags full of bats, balls and gloves.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Jimmy I can't do this by myself -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the roster and schedule. I'm goin' to the New York office for three weeks, a training seminar.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: How my gonna get my money? JIMMY is already pulling away, CONOR jogs alongside the car. JIMMY offers out the window...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Ellen will have your check every Monday. JIMMY motions to ELLEN, the CUTE RFCEPTIONIST sitting in the passenger seat. She smiles. JIMMY zooms off, raising dust from the dry lot behind the backstop. CONOR stands amidst the swirling dust and swirling kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR has somehow managed to corral all 7 boys into the graffiti laden dugout. He attempts to take roll.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Alonzo Ray Peetes? The kid with the blue bat responds.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: What's up motherfucka? The kids laugh at his funny delivery.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What position do you play?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Big Willie. More laughs.  ALONZO (cont'd) Whatever, back catcher, center field, I got mad power. I pound it to the gate yo. He exchanges a hard hand slap with MAURICE the tall lanky kid. These boys are obviously the alpha males.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Frederick Payne the second? No response as the kids all point to the short stocky kid listening to his walkman. CONOR (cont'd) What position does he play?

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: He says he can pitch, coach Conor, but might pitch too.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Calvert Jefferson Tibbs, my mama says I could play anywhere, what with my asthma and all I should probably play first. I gotta keep my sugar up too. Y'know my mama says that some boys just plain big boned -

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: And some boys just plain fat ass. Again ALONZO exchanges slaps with MAURICE. The kids laugh. Suddenly they get quiet as two men are standing behind CONOR. One is MATT HYLAND, a white yuppie dressed in clean coaching clothes. The other is AL CARTER a black man in a sweat suit and dress shoes. They wait for CONOR to turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Matt Hyland head of the coaches committee, are you the Kikuyus?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What? ALONZO jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yeah bitch, we the Kikuyus, whassup?

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: (checking his pad) Where's James Devlin from Morgan Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: He's the head coach I'm assisting him, he has business out of town.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: Well, you've got what? Six or seven kids here? You gotta be able to field a team or the league will drop you. CONOR could care less.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'll tell Jimmy that-

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: This is Al Carter he's the commissioner of the league.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Last year was a mess we had to cancel games because we'd show up and the other team would have five kids. Waste of everybody's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just wanna save everyone alotta trouble, if you can't field a team, drop out. CONOR stares incredulously at the two politicians attempting to leverage him out of a situation he has no interest in being in.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Talk to Jimmy Devlin and Morgan Stanley and submit a roster by Friday. AL CARTER and MATT HYLAND saunter off proud of their stance. CONOR looks back to the seven KIKUYUS who have heard and understand their fate. CALVERT pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Tiki and Ray-Ray wanna play. CONOR fumbles with his sheet, he struggles to read the names.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Is that Tirakian Evans and Raymont Bennet?

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Yeah, Coach Conor 'dat Tiki and Ray-Ray, but Missus Wilkes ain't never gonna let them play. The kids explode in impersonations of MRS. WILKES, who from these impressions is a mean woman.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who's Mrs. Wilkes?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: She teach fifth grade at Immaculate Conception -

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: She's real mean Coach -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a old nasty lady who tell your moms everything "bout what homework you don't do, she called my moms every night last year.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: And she won't let these guys play?

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Coach Conor she told they moms that they can't play ball until they do these book reports.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I can tell ya, Tiki ain't doin' shit.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Ray-Ray neither, yo. Them motherfuckas is like, "quit that noise bitch". CONOR raises his bandaged hand in an attempt for control.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Can we try to cool it on the use of "Motherfuckers" and "bitch". The kids get quiet for a second. CONOR stares at his roster thinking.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Where's Immaculate Conception? Maybe I should try to talk to Mrs. Wilkes. FREDDY who has been silent the whole time pipes way up.

dialogues.speaker: NOOO
dialogues.text: They all turn to FREDDY who takes off his head phones and then very earnestly offers. FREDDY (cont'd) No Coach, that bitch is one mean old motherfucka. The team laughs at FREDDY's disregard for the "Motherfucker" ban.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Alright, umh... well I gotta talk to Coach Devlin and figure this out. The sound of unbelievably heavy bass emanates from a "83 Monte Carlo that slowly prowls through the lot behind the backstop. The players on the field all stand still and watch it pass. CONOR notes the reaction from the team.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Coach it's gettin' dark, we gotta go soon.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who's in that car.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: They "folks", they local, it's cool.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Folks?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yeah, "folks", they ain't the problem, "Disciples", they the problem. CONOR absorbs this information before addressing the team. He tries to organize the next practice as the kids are antsy to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umh...Thursday at four o'clock here. The kids have already broken into small factions as they map out their routes home.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Yo Lonzo, how you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Up Carson, to Division then across Beaumont then 27th back to Carson at Cabrini.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: I was gonna go down Carson and through the school yard back to Cabrini.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: My mom's meetin' me at Pizza pizza, I'm not walking by myself. CALVERT nervously runs to catch FREDDY.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Freddy, wait up, I wanna go with you to Pizza pizza. CONOR curiously watches as the kids attack the darkening landscape with military efficiency. Three separate groups tight together, trying to get safely back to the Cabrini Projects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALONZO and MAURICE walk shoulder to shoulder up CARSON street overly aware of everyone they see.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Wanna just cut up 25th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever, I don't always walk the folks loop, fuck the Disciples. A volley of gun fire is heard a few blocks away, the boys stop for one second.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO AND MAURICE
dialogues.text: Glock, nine millimeter. The boys continue to walk, shoulders closer trying not to appear scared.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You know about my Ka-rah-tay right?

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: You mean karate?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Nah, it's Ka-rah-tay, I learned it from my cousin who was in Japan in the Army. MAURICE's silence is a tacit acceptance of ALONZO's lie. ALONZO (cont'd) Lightning quick. ALONZO stops in his tracks and slaps MAURICE in the chest. MAURICE stops walking. ALONZO assumes a pose placing his hands by his ears like claws, eyes bugged wide open and standing on one foot. ALONZO (cont'd) This is the tiger, no man can defend himself from the fury of a well trained ka-rah-tay tiger man. MAURICE nods his head wanting desperately to believe that ALONZO really has uncontrollable deadly martial arts skills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah Lonzo, the tiger, I heard a that. ALONZO retracts his pose as if coming out of a trance.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yeah, I only use the tiger when I fight like a dozen guys.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Yeah that's right.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: More than that I use the bear.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Right... (a beat) What's the bear again? MAURICE looks to ALONZO who we get the feeling has exhausted his ka-rah-tay repertoire.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I can't show you, secret code of ka-rah-tay honor.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: That's cool. The boys have continued down the street and have come to CARSON and 24th Street. We can see the tall buildings of the Cabrini Green Housing Project two short blocks away. Just as they're about to cross 24 they see a gang of teenagers wearing an assortment of Georgetown Hoya gear; Starter pullovers, wool caps, baseball hats. Without speaking ALONZO and MAURICE put their heads down and continue quickly up CARSON Ave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 1978 Toyota Celica pulls up to the curb and CALVERT gets out and we can see FREDDY and FREDDY'S MOM in the car. FREDDY'S MOM hands a small pizza box out the window.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Thanks ma'am, I'll finish it tonight. The car pulls away and CALVERT studies the four dimly lit buildings arranged in a U-shaped courtyard. He fixes on the entrance to an orange high rise 100 yards away. Jamaican music floats out of a distant window and a group of older men drink from bottles in bags at a picnic table. The asphalt circle in the middle of the four buildings is dark but we can see shadows of people moving around. Groups of young men stand on the sidewalk. Some slowly troll on B.M.X bikes watching every car for brake lights. If a car slows down they circle for a sale. CALVERT begins to walk towards the orange building, his breath is labored by asthma and fear. He sees a shadow out of the corner of his eye and he instinctively runs toward the nearest building. CALVERT busts through the lobby door of a blue building and presses his chubby frame against the cinder block wall. He pulls out his inhaler and takes two quick hits. The flame of a lighter illuminates the otherwise dark stairwell as a rail thin woman lights the end of what used to be the plastic tube of a bic pen. We now see that there's a guy with her and CALVERT goes through a door to the hallway of the first floor of the building.  CALVERT continues down the hallway and we see the doors of different apartments left open. The sound of T.V.'s squawking and babies crying accompany the toys and kids that litter the thin hall. CALVERT gets to the other end of the hall and goes in to the stairwell. CALVERT steps over a sleeping body and again ventures outside. CALVERT again fixes on the entrance to the orange building that is now only 20 yards away. He takes one more hit from his inhaler and sprints as best he can to the steps of the orange building. CALVERT bursts through the door of the orange building and immediately bounds up the stairs. He turns the corner and THREE YOUNG MEN are standing around a small radio listening to hip-hop music and sharing a 40 ounce malt liquor. CALVERT passes them with his head down and the boys don't even acknowledge him. CALVERT uses the key hanging by a shoestring around his neck to open apartment 207.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TICKY and CONOR are scalping tickets in what appears to be a dead market. Other scalpers laze about and compete for the same sales. TICKY and CONOR are mid- conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I just can't believe you're going to some school in the projects to beg some old nun for ball players?  A HEAVY SET MAN in a Blackhawks jacket approaches them. The HEAVY

dialogues.speaker: HEAVY SET MAN
dialogues.text: I need three in the blues for 50.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (to the man) Fuck you 85, (to Ticky) I got no choice Jimmy's payin' my juice with Duffy, if I don't field a team the league drops us, I don't get my money. SET MAN re-approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HEAVY SET MAN
dialogues.text: I got 65 take it or leave it.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You take it, and shove it up your ass -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, 85 you fat fucker. (to Ticky) These kids are scary, they all live in Cabrini, they got gangs, I gotta get out.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you gotta get out, Cabrini's a shithole those kids are killers. They'll kill ya, maybe not today but-

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Could you tap your mom for a coupla bucks 'till I can-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's not havin' it, she cut me off. HEAVY SET MAN makes a last effort.

dialogues.speaker: HEAVY SET MAN
dialogues.text: C'mon guys it's my kid's birthday, 70 for the three in the blues.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Would you kiss my ass already? Can't you see we're tryin' to figure somethin' out here? I feel like smackin' you in the head, I do.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Gimme 75. The HEAVY SET MAN digs deep, obviously going over his budget.

dialogues.speaker: HEAVY SET MAN
dialogues.text: Jesus, I heard that Baby Bop ain't even in this show.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why don't you not worry about Baby Bop. TICKY peels off the three tickets from an efficiently arranged wad. CONOR (cont'd) I'll give you a baby bop in the head. The HEAVY SET MAN scampers away, his illegal transaction complete. CONOR reflects to TICKY. CONOR (cont'd) What's Baby Bop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Barney's the big dinosaur right?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. TICKY and CONOR start walking towards the Civic Center, we begin pulling back to a wide shot.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Well Baby Bop is like this fuckin' uh, what d'ya call it...baby purple dinosaur.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No shit, dinosaurs on ice.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: And they skate around with that broad from the Olympics with the horsey face? As we go wider we see the marquee for the Civic Center. It reads, "Barney and Friends on Ice".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train thins as it continues south to Cabrini. We watch CONOR who tries not to make eye contact with the other passengers who all appear to be going nowhere in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR exits the train and lights a cigarette. He goes down the steps of the platform. He looks out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR takes a moment to bolster his courage. He takes in the sights and sounds of the playground that is  overrun with boys and girls screaming with after school energy. He heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR stands awkwardly in the doorway of the office waiting to be noticed. Finally an older woman wearing a large sweater and a large cross addresses him from behind a desk.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MOLINA
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm Conor O'Neill.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MOLINA
dialogues.text: I'm Sister Molina.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm here to see Sister Wilkes? I called earlier. SISTER MOLINA pauses before sharing a huge grin.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MOLINA
dialogues.text: Sister Wilkes, of course, Sister Wilkes has the last room on this hall to the left. CONOR pauses to take in the Cheshire cat's grin that SISTER MOLINA can't help. CONOR leaves the Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR slowly walks the ball preparing for his encounter with SISTER WILKES. He gets to the last door, it's closed but a stenciled sign reads "Wilkes". CONOR breathes, then knocks.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes? CONOR speaks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Wilkes, I'm Conor O'Neill I wanted to talk to you about... Suddenly the door is thrust open. Due to fire codes the classroom doors open out and CONOR gets whacked in the head as he stumbles to get out of the way. An attractive young woman stands in the doorway looking at CONOR who is collecting his wits and his Cubs hat from the floor. CONOR (cont'd) It's okay, it's just my head.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Who are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Sister Wilkes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'm Miss Wilkes. CONOR is confused and treads lightly.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Do you teach here?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I was expecting an older woman. CONOR hunches over slightly mimicking the kids impressions of Miss Wilkes. ELIZABETH doesn't smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'm not a nun.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Thank God... I mean that's great... or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: well? CONOR pulls a crumpled piece of paper from his pocket and reads

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Is Tirakian Evans and Raymont Bennett in your class? She corrects his grammar.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are they in my class? Yes they are in my class.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I need them to play baseball for the Kikuyus little league team.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You should take that up with their mothers.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: But the kids told me -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes, both mothers agreed that the boys need to read one book before playing baseball this spring.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hey, I got no problem with that. Reading's real good... for kids. studies CONOR'S casual outfit.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You work for Morgan Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (defiantly lying) Yes.  ELIZABETH fights off a smile. She knows he's lying but there's something noble and charming about his style.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What deal did you blow?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're not coaching this team by choice.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (more lying) My associate James Devlin is in New York for three weeks so I volunteered to help out. (even bigger lie) I would have loved to coach this team. I was away on business in... Canada the day... Mr. Morgan and... Mr. Stanley chose the coach.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (goes along with it) Canada? Was it nice?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (struggling) Lovely, I was in the... umh... business part... the whole time though.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well it's great you teach them baseball but unfortunate that no one spends time helping them to read. She begins to shut the door. CONOR jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm Conor.  He waits for her reply, finally she gives in.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm only helping out with the team for two weeks but I'm willing to get together with you and help with the boys. Why don't we exchange numbers and-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Better yet, I'll give you the books the boys are supposed to read and you can read them and talk to Tirakian and Raymont about their reports. CONOR has no choice but to withstand the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: God, that would be... great. Good idea. ELIZABETH hands him a couple of tattered paperbacks. CONOR smiles as ELIZABETH closes the door. What a tangled web he's woven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual Wednesday night crowd inhabits Duffy's. A college basketball game holds the attention of the barflies and the BARTENDER we remember from the opening scene. TICKY sits at a stool near a familiar window that's boarded up. CONOR enters and slams the paperbacks on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Gimme a bat and a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor O'Neill, coach of the crack babies.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Do you realize that that's all you ever say to me, "fuck you". Hey Conor, "fuck you". Wanna go to the game? "Fuck you". Hey Conor fuck you, "fuck you". The BARTENDER stares him down.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: O'Neill, Duffy's here. Tell me you got his money.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Listen "no neck", what's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Peter.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Good Peter, "fuck you", go get Duffy. The BARTENDER glares at CONOR before going into the back room. CONOR turns to TICKY. CONOR (cont'd) I can't coach that team, I gotta get out. I'm serious, I'm bailin' out.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: How did it go with the nuns? Did you tell them "fuck you?" CONOR remembers ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, she was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You picked up a nun?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Ticky... "Fuck you".

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You still want you're half of the Blackhawks seats I got?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (remembering) Yeah, where are they?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I'm gettin' 'em tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Bring 'em to the little league field on Carson tomorrow before five.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: The field in Cabrini? CONOR grabs TICKY's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Don't screw me Ticky, I'm not in the mood right now. I need that money.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I'll be there at 5. DUFFY carries a bat as he approaches CONOR. CONOR grabs the paperbacks as he stands. CONOR (cont'd) Easy slugger, alright, relax.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You got some cabbage for me?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Can we talk outside? Without the bat?  DUFFY studies CONOR's face which appears genuine. He hands the bat to the BARTENDER and follows CONOR outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR and DUFFY stand on the sidewalk. CONOR shuffles his feet, his head is down as he begins...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Duffy, you knew my dad... and I wouldn't be callin' ina favor if I wasn't completely racked.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You smashed up my bar.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You know that I will pay it all back, I just need time.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: It ain't my money. I can't carry you this time. It's six grand of somebody else's money. Somebody who didn't know your father and doesn't give a fuck about you or me, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'll help run the book, take bets, I'll bring in business. DUFFY gets quiet, he's completely backed down. A beat then...

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Nah, it's no good. Listen, I gave 'm your name ‘cause I couldn't carry it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) What? Some goombahs gonna come break my thumb? DUFFY's quiet, shakes his head. CONOR gets scared. CONOR (cont'd) Duffy, I'm desperate, I'm coaching a little league team in the projects for a guy who's payin' me 500 a week... but I'm payin' the Barber off, what should I do? Should I tell the Barber "fuck off"? Should I start payin' you 250 every week? DUFFY looks at CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Keep payin' the Barber, and don't come around here unless you got the money. DUFFY walks back into the bar. CONOR looks to the sky for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALONZO catches for CONOR who's halfheartedly hitting infield practice. CONOR is agitated as he attempts the appearance of holding a practice. He continually checks his watch and scours the landscape for TICKY. No sign of TICKY, but a serious looking black woman accompanies three young black boys.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yo coach, when we gonna hit? CONOR likes the idea of not having to hit ground balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out to Louis) What's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: That's Louis.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Louis, pitch batting practice. CONOR walks to the bleachers as LOUIS grabs a few tattered balls and storms the mound. ALONZO runs to the equipment and returns with his beat up blue softball bat.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You bustas betta back the hell up, Ima pound this shit to the gate. ALONZO does a practice swing "ritual" that rivals the flashiest in Major League Baseball. LOUIS throws a soft floater that ALONZO whiffs at. The team starts busting on ALONZO with a chorus of, "Shit the wind just picked up" and "yo you feel that breeze?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR talks with the woman and the boys.

dialogues.speaker: PEARLA EVANS
dialogues.text: I'm Pearla Evans and this one's Tirakian. She places her hand an the tallest boy's head. PEARLA EVANS (cont'd) This is my youngest, Jarius - The small boy pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evy body call me G-Baby, so- With a raise of her hand G-BABY ceases talking, PEARLA is living up to her stern reputation. PEARLA continues...

dialogues.speaker: PEARLA EVANS
dialogues.text: This is my sister's boy Raymont and I spoke to Miss Wilkes at the school and she said you agreed to help these boys with their assignments so they could play ball.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh... yeah... well that was before I had this business trip to -

dialogues.speaker: PEARLA EVANS
dialogues.text: Miss Wilkes said she had a good feeling about you so I figured I'd give it a try. CONOR smiles at the news.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Miss Wilkes said that?

dialogues.speaker: PEARLA EVANS
dialogues.text: No, actually she said she had a good feeling about them all playing ball but I'm tell you now Mr...?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Conor O'Neill.

dialogues.speaker: PEARLA EVANS
dialogues.text: O'Neill, you don't help these boys and they don't do this work. Hell will be paid with your ass.  The boys begin to giggle and with a look PEARLA EVANS silences them. PEARLA EVANS (cont'd) I trust I can reach you at Morgan Stanley to plana tutoring session?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Uh... yes, of course anytime.

dialogues.speaker: PEARLA EVANS
dialogues.text: Good, go on boys. The boys join their friends on the field as PEARLA leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR blows into his hands as he sits on the bleachers watching the debacle that batting practice has become. He checks his watch -- its 6:15 and no sign of TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (sotto) C'mon Ticky you're killin' me. CALVERT comes wheezing up to CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Coach Conor, we usually quit at 5:30 and my mama needs me home we eat around six thirty- CONOR cuts him off short.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Calvin, we'll be done soon, I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: I'm Calvert, Calvert Jefferson Tibbs.  CALVERT walks away defeated.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
dialogues.text: MAURICE bats as a laboring LOUIS still pitches. G-BABY and another boy are sitting near second base playing with the dirt. ALONZO calls from the outfield.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: C'mon Maurice, whack that shit to the gate! LOUIS is exhausted as he winds up and throws a pitch that hits MAURICE in the thigh. MAURICE drops the bat and rushes the mound. He begins posturing with LOUIS.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Whassup mothafucka? Huh? Roll up bitch. Roll up! The kids crowd the mound wanting a fight. No unity, just thirsty for blood.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: C'mon Louis you bitch, throw down.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yo Maurice drop his ass like a bad habit. CONOR has gotten there in time to realize that they would probably posture for a few days before they would actually throw a punch.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Alright, that's it. It's 6:30. Practice Saturday 1:00. The boys react to the time with alarm as they scramble to form allegiances for the walk home.  CALVERT runs to catch up with CONOR. He looks scared.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Coach Conor can I walk with you?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No, umh... I'm not goin' that way, sorry. CALVERT's eyes are wide in disappointed fear as he rushes off to collect his stuff. CONOR realizes that the boys are already packed into small groups and scurrying across the park in different directions. CALVERT struggles with his heavy knapsack. Candy spills out as he tries to hoist it onto his shoulder He panics as he collects the candy, trying to catch up with someone to walk home with. TICKY pulls up in a 1984 Buick Regal and CONOR rushes towards him. We can hear CONOR yelling about how late TICKY was, but we stay with... CALVERT lifts the knapsack and he can't get it on to his shoulder. CALVERT half carries and half drags it along the ground as he heads towards the ever darkening streets around the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night has fallen like rain on CALVERT who still struggles with his fear and his back pack. He's alone as he walks slowly towards the lights of the Cabrini Projects.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STREET
dialogues.text: ALONZO walks with TIKI and G-BABY as they cautiously take a circuitous route to Cabrini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all's cool wit me, I know ka-rah-tay.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: You mean karate and all that?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: It's pronounced kah-rah-tay.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: You know that judo and shit?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Hell yes.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Bullshit mothafucka, I could kick your monkey ass. ALONZO stops walking for a second and TIKI and G-BABY continue two steps before stopping to look back.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I'm gonna forget you said that. ALONZO buries the insult in the interest of getting home.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STREET
dialogues.text: CALVERT has literally come to a crossroads as he stares down a dim street. He looks the other way and sees an OLDER MAN in a long coat who wobbles as he walks. CALVERT can't decide which way to go, the man looks harmless enough. He begins down that street. CALVERT gets an uneasy feeling. Acting on instinct, he quickly turns around and heads the other way. He cuts through the playground of a nursery school. The knapsack is feeling lighter as he can see the street lamp of 26th and Cabrini about 40 yards away. He begins to walk casually and his breathing has subsided.  SUDDENLY he's knocked to the ground and two young KIDS are on him immediately. The KIDS try to pull CALVERT's knap sack away but CALVERT got tangled in the straps when he fell.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Take it! Just take it! CALVERT is trying to free himself from the bag as the two KIDS continue to wrestle with it. One of the KIDS whacks CALVERT in the head and he goes down flat. The other kid starts kicking CALVERT in an attempt to make him roll over. In a defensive reflex, CALVERT assumes the fetal position. As he curls up the knap sack comes free and one of the KIDS takes off with it. The other kid kicks CALVERT who has begun to hyperventilate causing an asthma attack. The strange barking noise coming from CALVERT's straining lungs upsets the remaining kid. The KID levels one last kick to CALVERT's head before taking off. CALVERT falls slowly to his back and his breathing calms as he loses consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calvert's mother LENORA TIBBS, a large woman in black tights, is talking to ELIZABETH in the hall outside CALVERT's room. CONOR catches them mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LENORA TIBBS
dialogues.text: Girl you can bet my big black butt Ima' call the league and raise hell, but I gots to have a cigarette. CONOR approaches ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: why did you keep them so late?! LENORA TIBBS jump in.

dialogues.speaker: LENORA TIBBS
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm the coach, Conor O'Neill.

dialogues.speaker: LENORA TIBBS
dialogues.text: I should beat your butt, I called you at Morgan Stanley and at first some little girl didn't even know who you were! Then some man named Devlin got on the phone and told me you were outta the office today. You in Lenora's dog house now!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Please take my home number. CONOR scrambles for a piece of paper and a pen. CONOR (cont'd) Always call my house, don't bother with Morgan Stanley they never know where I am. LENORA studies CONOR with a suspicious eye as she accepts the number.

dialogues.speaker: LENORA TIBBS
dialogues.text: Boy, Ima' have a cigarette then we gonna talk. You can't have them boys down there after dark. Thank Jesus for Calvert's strength. But I should still beat your butt. That smell? That might be a lawsuit. LENORA goes for a smoke and ELIZABETH turns to CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really blew it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, can you help me here? A NURSE comes out of CALVERT's room.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You guys should go in there, he's wondering where everyone went? CONOR and ELIZABETH go in to CALVERT's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CALVERT sits upright with an oxygen tube running into his nose. He has a fat lip and a scrape on his forehead, but all things considered he seems okay.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Calvert, I'm sorry, I should have called practice as soon as it got dark. CALVERT doesn't look at CONOR. CONOR (cont'd) I just came by because... as soon as you're ready, we expect you back. No response. CONOR (cont'd) And I needed to know what number uniform you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: You're never gonna stay being our coach. CONOR tries to dodge the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least till Coach Jimmy comes back from New York. LEENORA rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: LENORA TIBBS
dialogues.text: So how's my baby doin'? CONOR starts to slip out. LENORA TIBBS (cont'd) Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: 52 Coach. They all look to CALVERT who fixes on CONOR. CALVERT (cont'd) I want number 52, like Sosa. CONOR waves to CALVERT who just saved his hide. CONOR leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR shows up a few minutes late as the players are already trying to kill each other. ALONZO and TIKI are squared off.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Pay up bitch.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Kiss my ass mothakucka! CONOR jumps between the players and amidst the growing mob that again just wants to see blood.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Cool it. CONOR shoves ALONZO away from TIKI.  CONOR (cont'd) What's goin' on? G-BABY steps into the middle to explain.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Alright, lemme break it down right quick. Lonzo said he could catch any high pop anybody could throw. Tiki say "bullshit you a busta". Lonzo say, "roll up bitch". Tiki say "I'll give you all my gum if you can catch this ball." He threw it, Lonzo caught it. Lonzo say, "pay me motha fucka", Tiki say, "You a cheatin' bitch", no wait, Tiki say, "You a mocha fuckin' cheatin ass bitch". Then Lonzo say -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I got it, okay. I want everybody to take a position, infield, outfield, let's go. The players argue their way to their positions.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: CONOR hits a grounder that goes through FREDDY's legs, TIKI leads the team in teasing him. CONOR hits a fly ball that LOUIS charges in for only to watch it sail over his head. Again TIKI volleys insults at him and the team joins in. CONOR hits a hard line drive right at TIKI that he jumps out of the way of. The team is silent. CONOR stops.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What happened? The team is silent.  CONOR (cont'd) Tiki just jumped out of the way like a baby, why's everyone so quiet about it? MORE silence. CONOR (cont'd) What's up Tiki, you scared of the ball? TIKI glares at CONOR but says nothing. CONOR (cont'd) New rule, no one can say anything bad to anyone else on the field. Got it? Silence suggests acceptance as CONOR continues with infield practice. The practice is silent as players do a bit better without the fear of ridicule from their teammates. CONOR stops again. CONOR (cont'd) What? If you can't talk shit you got nothing to say? New rule you can only say good things to each other on the field. CONOR continues infield and the players remain silent. CONOR (cont'd) Let me hear some positive chatter. CONOR hits a ground ball to RAY-RAY who scoops it up and tosses it to ALONZO who's catching for CONOR. We hear a faint chorus of "Nice play Ray-Ray" and "Way to go Ray"... CONOR (cont'd) That's it guys, little louder.  We watch as the cheers get louder and more comfortable as it, appears that the players only needed an excuse to be supportive of each other. LOUIS gets bopped on the head and everyone is silent before ALONZO offers...

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Way to use your head Louis, alright. Practice lightens up as the players continue to laugh and cheer each other on. We see the seeds of a team.

dialogues.speaker: DUGOUT
dialogues.text: CONOR speaks to the team after practice.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Alright, so you all have probably heard what happened to Calvert.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Fat ass got beat down.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: He got jacked up yo, these four GD's had him pinned and one was gonna smoke him... RAY-RAY acts out his story using FREDDY as CALVERT. RAY-RAY (cont'd) He put the tech nine to his head and he pulled the trigger and... click it jammed. TIKI jumps in with his version.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Bullshit yo, all six of ‘em had glocks and they took turns beatin' black down with  they guns, like "Bap! Bap! Bap!".

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, my cousin seen ‘em, all his teeth knocked out and one eye was hangin' out all like... Ahhhhh! MAURICE parades down the dugout like a toothless freak with an eye hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay, listen he's gonna be fine, but it was my fault and I'm sorry. I gotta make sure we're outta here before dark. We’re gonna work out a carpool to take people home. CONOR starts to hand out packets to each player. The kids start tearing through the pages looking for the schedule.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: We play the Man dicks first? What kinda name is the Man dicks?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: It's Mandikes, every team in the league is named after a tribe in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: April 24th, winner group A plays winner group B in the... Championship.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Yo mothafucka we goin' to the ship. ALONZO and MAURICE exchange hand slaps, that starts a chant of "We goin' to the Ship'. CONOR can't help but smile at their spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TICKY is scalping tickets for a Blackhawks game. A purple 1996 Buick Roadmaster Stationwagon, complete with wood paneling, drives up to the curb. CONOR gets out.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Nice wheels soccer mom.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Really what's with the wagon?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: The suits at Morgan Stanley took shit for one of the kids gettin' beat up on his way home so they lent me this car to care ‘em home.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Who got beat up? Two STRAIGHT LACED TEENAGERS are nervously waiting for TICKY's attention.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Calvert Jefferson Tibbs.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Oh, that's the fat kid right?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, the fat kid. How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You've told me about every kid on the team. well, that's shitty, I hate when people fuck with kids. With that TICKY finally addresses the two kids nearby.  TICKY (cont'd) How can I help you fellas?

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT LACED KID
dialogues.text: Mister you just sold us tickets to last night's game. Like a reflex, TICKY grabs inside his vest as if fora gun. He accompanies this move with a scary verbal assault.

dialogues.speaker: CRACK
dialogues.text: The STRAIGHT LACED KIDS immediately bolt in fear. CONOR shakes his head at TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You're unbelievable. How we doin' today?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: We?... We aren't doin' so good. San Jose's not such a hot ticket.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Did the bulls cover last night?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Yup, they won by 9.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Shit, I couldn't get any action. I need to find someone who'll take a big bet.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Fink's minimum bet is two grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy in the firehouse?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Yeah Fink the guy above the firehouse, why?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I hate this life Ticky, I gotta get out. I just need to be right once, y'know? One big bet to get me even, get me out.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You want out?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Out. No more fuckin' bookies, no more coachin' this bullshit team for Jimmy. I don't have the stomach for this life anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You're down like 11 grand.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I wanna lay 12 g's.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: 12 grand? On what?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Bulls have never lost at home to Miami. TICKY stops scanning for sales to look CONOR in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You're serious about this.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: They play Miami on the 26th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't do this.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don't have a choice. Take me to meet Fink. TICKY looks at CONOR and then stares blankly into the pre-game hockey crowd.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll take you to see Fink. CONOR und TICKY exchange quiet head nods, already feeling the tension of the twelve thousand dollar bet.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR'S ROUTINE
dialogues.text: The Rolling Stones, "Heartbreaker" helps to narrate CONOR's weekly routine. We see CONOR pull clothes off the floor and onto his body. He stumbles out of his apartment building, affixing dark shades as the light of day hurts our evening dweller. CONOR leaves his shades on inside the Morgan Stanley building as he collects his check from the CUTE RECEPTIONIST. CONOR lunges at her just to scare her, she jumps about ten feet. He laughs as he goes on with his day. CONOR stands in line at a check cashing store ina strip mall. He appears at home with other customers who no longer maintain legitimate bank accounts. He cashes his check. CONOR strolls into the BARBER SHOP and the collection of men stand and surround him. CONOR pulls out an envelope and presents it to the BARBER'S SON and everyone relaxes. CONOR's not the most welcome person at the shop but they're happy to see some money.  CONOR stands outside a pizza window counting the loose change and few single dollars he's got. He buys one slice and a single beer with not much money to spare. The Rolling Stones continue to serenade CONOR as he ends up back in his tiny apartment eating the day's only meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH has begun the day's lesson. We see that TIKI, RAY-RAY, CALVERT and ALONZO are all in her class. CALVERT is standing by his chair reading an essay about his experience.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Four Spanish men with hiking boots had surrounded me close. I could tell they were "banditos" because they had taco breath and they called me "hombre". I spun around to hit the biggest one. I punched him in the gut and as he was falling he grabbed my backpack. I said, "Stop, you banditos I don't want to have to hit anyone else." But because they were Spanish they didn't understand me. Two more jumped me and I kicked one of them in his... (embarrassed to read "nuts") ...in the... (improvises) ... between his legs. He went down but two more kept comin'. And I was madder. Real madder, real real mad, and the madder I got the stronger I got. So I tied up in a hand lock with a bandito just like when "Stone Cold Steve Austin" on Monday Nitro  of the World wrestling Federation ties up with some busta that you know he's gonna beat down. My mouth banged on his head and that was where I got my fat lip. (Calvert smiles before...) The end.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Where'd you get yo fat butt? The class giggles until ELIZABETH scolds ALONZO.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Alonzo, enough. (praising Calvert) Very Nice Calvert, excellent use of first person narrative. You're story was very descriptive, I felt scared of the banditos. ELIZABETH is looking at CALVERT's essay as she continues. ELIZABETH (cont'd) Does anyone remember what we call the device Calvert uses when he compares... ELIZABETH realizes the kids are all looking at the open door. She looks to find... CONOR standing in the doorway with a large gray wool suit jacket and white polo shirt with a tie. He also wears gray dress pants that don't match his jacket and are short enough to show off his white tube socks and deck shoes. An old plastic and chrome brief case rounds out his attempt to appear as if he just came from the office.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Miss Wilkes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Neill. Fresh from the office? The kids giggle at CONOR's appearance. RAY-RAY pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yo Coach wassup with them pants? Expecting a flood?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I thought today was the day Tiki and Ray-Ray were going to talk about a "Wrinkle in Time" and I came down to help out. ELIZABETH smiles, admiring the effort.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That's correct. Everyone this is Mr. O'Neill who coaches a baseball team that some of our young men play on and he has taken time out of his busy day to help out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: A Wrinkle in Time is an important book and I like it very much. CONOR places his briefcase on a small desk and opens it upside down causing the contents to spill out. The only things in the briefcase were a copy of Sports Illustrated, cigarettes, a brush, "A Wrinkle in Time" and some chewing gum. The kids laugh and ELIZABETH smiles as CONOR scrambles for damage control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids seem to be relatively interested in the discussion as RAY-RAY holds forth in opposition to a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just sayin' it ain't like that. Fantasy ain't reality. I like to read stuff that's real.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Give me an example.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Michael Jordan's book.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That was a biography, that's the real story of his life. This is fiction, the story is made up, it's meant to entertain you, to make you think. RAY-RAY nods his head in understanding. ELIZABETH turns to TIKI. ELIZABETH (cont'd) Tirakian you've been silent the whole time. All you'll say is you didn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If you can't say more than that I'm gonna have to assume you still haven't read it and your mom will want me to call her. CONOR shares an uncomfortable look with ELIZABETH. We focus now on TIKI who looks nervous. ELIZABETH (cont'd) Did you read this book?

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something about it.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: It was booty. A small laugh from the class attempts to break the tension.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll talk to your mom tonight. ELIZABETH starts towards her desk, TIKI pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: That girl Meg is dumb. ELIZABETH turns to him. TIKI (cont'd) Cause she think her dads comin' back from wherever. And I think that's a stupid thing to believe in. That girl and her moms both trippin' cause where I'm from... ain't nobody's father come back. It is silent as TIKI's truthful interpretation is understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see the opposing team warming up on the field that has been freshly lined with chalk and slightly groomed for the first game. The MANDIKES are wearing black and yellow uniforms that are complete with stirrup socks and matching undershirts. JIMMY drives up in his BMW and jumps out, leaving the car running. He grabs a tattered cardboard box from the back seat and hustles towards the KIKUYUS dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY hands CONOR a box and an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Here you go buddy, the uniforms and next week's check. Good luck today.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I take it your not stayin'.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Can't, sorry next time. JIMMY scampers back to his car

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Thanks, thanks for giving back to the community!... dickhead. CONOR stands at the mouth of the dugout holding a tattered cardboard box. He reaches in and begins to hand old blue tee shirts and hats to the players. They react to the worn, cheaply printed shirts that read "Morgan Stanley Kikuyus".

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I want number 7.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Just take a shirt that fits and pass them down. G-BABY holds a shirt to his face.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: This shirt smells like my grandma. CALVERT joins the team in the dug out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Good to see you Calvert, who's got number 12.  MAURICE fires it at CONOR who hands it to CALVERT. CONOR (cont'd) Calvert this is the biggest shirt, everybody, they go up in size from 1 to 12. 1 to 4 are small 5 to 8 are medium, 6 to 9 are large so on.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Yo I need a shirt.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who's got number 11?

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Give it to Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: But where's my shirt? CONOR does a quick count to realize that there is 13 players, he already knows there are only 12 shirts.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: G-Baby c'mere I wanna talk to you. Everybody play catch in the outfield. The players bound out to the field pairing up for catch. G-BABY mopes over to CONOR who bends down to talk to him. CONOR (cont'd) How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: I'll be nine in October.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be nine before August to play in the league. G-BABY, who's always tough, begins to cry. CONOR (cont'd) But there's only 12 uniforms and 13 players so, I gotta give the guys who are old enough first pick. G-BABY nods his head, trying to compose himself as tears stream down his face.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: But I'm on the team right?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hell yes mothafucka. G-BABY smiles at CONOR's intentionally funny use of "mothafucka". G-BABY tries to rebound quickly by grabbing his glove and running towards the outfield. CONOR watches him go and then looks up to see PEARLA EVANS staring at him from the bleachers. CONOR stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR reads the line-up off the back of a torn piece of a cigarette carton-

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Ray-Ray you're up first and playing shortstop, Alonzo you bat second and you're gonna start as pitcher, Freddy third base - ALONZO springs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I'm the best player on the team.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: We gonna get bitch slapped with you pitchin' them cream puffs over the plate.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You wanna set it off right here? ALONZO steps to TIKI who stands up proving his size advantage over ALONZO's big mouth.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Nigga please, I beg you, go for yours. TIKI begins shoving ALONZO back with his chest. The rest of the KIKUYUS start goading both boys in an attempt to incite a fight. A lack of unity prevails as CONOR pulls them apart.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Save it for the game, let's go. Ray-Ray's up, Alonzo's on deck. ALONZO walks to the on-deck circle staring at TIKI, refusing to back down.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The opposing MANDIKES move the ball smoothly around the infield, warming up. CONOR looks to see about 8 parents in the bleachers behind the MANDIKES bench. CONOR turns to the KIKUYUS side to see PEARLA EVANS on the top bench of the bleachers and two teenage girls sharing a cigarette oblivious to the game. FIRST PITCH is a smoking fastball right down the plate, RAY-RAY jumps out of the batter's box. The  umpire hollers, "Strike one!", and things get worse from there.
