dialogues.speaker: THE MANDIKES SLAUGHTER OF THE KIKUYUS
dialogues.text: RAY-RAY, ALONZO and FREDDY all strike out on three pitches. ALONZO walks the bases loaded and then starts finding the plate only to see the MANDIKES nailing the ball through the infield and over the heads of the outfielders. CONOR shuffles nervously, checks his watch, he is embarrassed by his team's obvious lack of practice. A MANDIKE player hits a screaming ground ball to third that FREDDY makes a miraculously lucky play on. FREDDY immediately throws the ball back to ALONZO on the pitcher's mound as if he were in batting practice. ALONZO throws the ball over CALVERT's head and into right field and the circus of errors and fighting begins.

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL GAME
dialogues.text: TIKI bats with a determined face, the pitch, he swings and hits a long shot into right field. He admires it before running to first. TIKI runs straight at first base and stops to look for the ball. When TIKI realizes that the outfielder is running after it he heads for second.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Go Tiki! Keep Goin! TIKI makes it home well before the ball is retrieved and the KIKUYUS score their first run. CONOR gives him a hand slap and a few other players offer halfhearted shakes as well. It's obvious this  team is still more interested in individual performance.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: A small MANDIKE player is called out on strikes and the KIKUYUS shuffle in to bat for the top of the sixth. The MANDIKE COACH approaches CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: MANDIKE COACH
dialogues.text: I guess that's it, I mean the league says we're not supposed to start an inning after 6:30.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MANDIKE COACH
dialogues.text: Well yeah it's 6:37 and we’re up 16 to 1 so...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: That's cool, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KIKUYUS BENCH
dialogues.text: The finger pointing is rampant as the disappointed tempers of the KIKUYUS are flaring.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Freddy don't even know where to throw the ball.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shut up Ray-Ray, least he ran after it when it went by, shit went through your legs like 5 times.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Lonzo you a little bitch, least you throw like one.  ALONZO grabs TIKI's hat off his head and throws it in his face. TIKI shoves ALONZO against the fence. The team cheers for blood as ALONZO jumps at TIKI and they tie up in headlocks and begin the mean choreography of a twelve year old fight for pride. CONOR returns to see the melee and immediately tears TIKI off of ALONZO who was beginning to lose the fight. TIKI stands and steps away from CONOR and the team. TIKI (cont'd) Fuck all y'all, you suck.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Tiki your close to bein' done.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Nah, Fuck you, I'm done. I 'm out, this team sucks. TIKI throws his hat at ALONZO as a parting gesture before walking away. CONOR spies the faces of the defeated team and ina weak moment attempts to swing morale.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Anybody hungry? How' bout pizza? The team is interested but needs the magic phrase. CONOR (cont'd) I'm payin'. The boys erupt with "hell yeah's", G-BABY announces...

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: I'm down with that shit mothafucka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KIKUYUS have overtaken two booths near the back of the store. ALONZO continues to roust FREDDY for his mistakes and we still see a great deal of finger pointing and name calling.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: If this was a team with try- outs, me Maurice and Tiki would be the only ones would make it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Dat's bullshit, I'd make it, I ain't no busta.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You ain't got skills like Reese and me, we best on the team. ALONZO exchanges a hand slap with MAURICE, who's quiet as usual.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: And that black and yellow team just beat our ass. You the best on a team that sucks. That ain't shit. ALONZO levels a look at G-BABY that's meant to intimidate. G-BABY returns it, never one to back down.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA COUNTER
dialogues.text: CONOR looks nervously at the cash register and the growing number of sodas being placed on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GUY
dialogues.text: Three large pie, nine sodas, 44.65. CONOR recounts the 18 dollars in his hand, he pulls some tickets out of his bill fold.  The black The other expense.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You like hockey? Blackhawks fans? PIZZA GUY stares at CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GUY
dialogues.text: Sure, I take the wife and kids to the Negro Hockey Hall of Fame every year. black PIZZA GUY has a laugh at CONOR's

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GUY
dialogues.text: How many black hawks are there? Shouldn't they be called the white hawks?

dialogues.speaker: OTHER PIZZA GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we just worry bout all the brothers playin' hockey, cause God forbid the ice melt you know niggas can't swim. The two PIZZA GUYS have successfully cracked themselves up and left CONOR feeling like an ass who still only has 18 dollars to pay for a 44 dollar tab. The PIZZA tickets.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'll give you two loge seats for the Bulls-Mavericks on Sunday. GUY composes himself and examines the

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GUY
dialogues.text: For the pizza? CONOR (defeated) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done deal. CONOR struggles with the soda tray as the other PIZZA GUY makes a last jab.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER PIZZA GUY
dialogues.text: I'll throw on pepperoni for two more seats for our girls.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP
dialogues.text: The kids are quieter now that they're stuffed with pizza and soda.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: If I get a homerun next game, you gotta buy me pizza again.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Nah, every run I score I get one slice. CONOR seems preoccupied as he stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You bustas trippin' only me gettin' pizza every game. MVP, most valuable pizza eater. FREDDY speaks, a country never heard from.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I should be pitcher. CONOR turns to the rarely heard voice.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You wanna pitch Freddy?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. CONOR smiles at the only respect he's been paid in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can pitch on Wednesday. FREDDY smiles as he puts his headphones on. MAURICE weighs in.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Coach, do we have any chance of gettin' trophies this year? CONOR pulls the rolled up paperwork from his pocket, he examines it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: There are... 8 teams in the league, we play everyone twice and then it looks like... yeah, the top four teams make the playoffs. Yeah, we gotta win more games then we lose.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Then we could go to the "ship?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We could.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: We goin' to the ship! We goin' to the ship! RAY-RAY gets up and creates a dance move to go with his chant, the other KIKUYUS join him. CONOR smiles at their youthful optimism as he thinks of his own sinking ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR's Stationwagon trolls along Lafayette Street in front of the familiar quad of buildings that most of his players live in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the wagon we see an exhausted CONOR sitting with his lone passenger ALONZO.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: All right Lonzo, this is it right? ALONZO stares at his building which is in the center of the quad, 150 yards away. With his hand on the door handle, ALONZO watches the midweek night life of Cabrini and turns to CONOR-

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Don't you wanna see my house? CONOR senses ALONZO's fear and complies by turning the car off and getting out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR feels a strange fear of exposure walking on the vast concrete lawn towards ALONZO's building which now appears to be getting farther away. A strange noise is followed by laughter as they occasionally pass the ghost-like face of an evening dweller. Guys drink out of bags and a girl in her 20's strolls by appearing lost as she carries a pair of plastic white pumps. CONOR and ALONZO finally reach the entrance to the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR squints from the shocking contrast from the black night to the blinding yellow of the cheap buzzing halogen tubes that light the thin hallway. CONOR is a step behind ALONZO who moves by instinct over the toys and around the shopping carts that clutter the hall. The paper thin carpet doesn't  muffle the sounds of the TV's that baby-sit the kids in each apartment. CONOR's curiosity has him peering into each open apartment as he makes his way down the hall. He notices something similar in each apartment. He stops. ALONZO eventually looks back.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Everyone is sittin' on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You stay below the window. ALONZO stands in his open doorway waiting to say good- bye.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Bullets. CONOR emits a small astonished laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What d'ya do around here for fun?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Play baseball with you. CONOR absorbs the compliment, ALONZO goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR nervously counts the numbers of KIKUYUS who have shown up for their second game.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay we got exactly nine guys today, everybody plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opposing team is the Continental Bank BANTUS. They wear red and white uniforms as they warm up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yo Coach, I could pitch? You know I got mad skills right?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Freddy's gonna start today. We see FREDDY intently listening to his walkman and swaying to the music. CONOR offers him the brand new game ball. CONOR (cont'd) You ready Freddy? FREDDY smiles as he palms the game ball, still lost in his music. CONOR lifts off the headphones. CONOR (cont'd) You want me to hold your walkman. FREDDY smiles and shakes his head, "no". CONOR shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BANTU GAME
dialogues.text: The BANTU pitcher is a tall skinny kid with no control. He immediately walks the first four KIKUYUS giving them their first lead of the season. ALONZO pokes a grounder over first base and turns it into a "homerun" when the BANTU's make two throwing errors. MAURICE follows with a legitimate drive over the left fielder's head that allows him to jog around to score.

dialogues.speaker: GAME
dialogues.text: With the score 7-0 KIKUYUS, FREDDY takes the mound for the first time. FREDDY's walkman is clipped to the  waistband of his baggy jeans. The headphones are wrapped over his hat that's tightly pulled down, almost covering his eyes. The BANTUS laugh at FREDDY who occasionally dances to the song only he can hear. He is oblivious to the BANTUS mockery as he sets to face the first batter. After a high, fluid leg kick delivery, FREDDY fires the first pitch down the heart of the plate - strike one. He is magnificent. FREDDY strikes out the side on 11 pitches. CONOR smiles with pride as he exchanges a hand slap with the almost embarrassed FREDDY who quietly takes his seat on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: BANTUS GAME
dialogues.text: FREDDY continues to amaze as the BANTUS prove that the only thing they had going for them were those red and white uniforms. The KIKUYUS win it going away, the team is in high spirits as they sing the obligatory "2-4-6-8" chant to the humiliated BANTUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR stands by the stationwagon as he sorts through the after school throng of kids leaving school. ALONZO, RAY-RAY and CALVERT walk with ELIZABETH towards the car. CONOR waves from the curb. The boys wear their KIKUYUS hats with pride as they fight for the front seat. CONOR smiles at ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We won our last game.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I heard, 9 to 3 over the Bantus. CONOR is self-conscious about his pride and reels it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm just tryin' to help out until my colleague returns from New York.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That's great of you to take time out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Listen, why don't we have dinner tonight? I mean what good is an expense account if you don't get to pad it once in a while?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I can't - it's a school night. Another time.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: After our game On Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Boys would love to see you there. ELIZABETH smiles at this sweet but obvious manipulation.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay. CONOR returns the smile and hops in the wagon as ELIZABETH walks away. CALVERT pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Coach, you're not really tryin' to get wit' Miss Wilkes are you? CONOR looks at the expectant faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Good, cause I already tried, and she ain't havin' it.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. She dissed me. CONOR hides his smile, these guys are serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KIKUYUS wait to take the infield against the MAU MAUS. We see that the MAU MAUS suffer from the same uniform problem that the KIKUYUS do. The MAU MAUS wear black hats and black tee shirts that we can tell don't match. Some have numbers and some don't.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Look at these bustas, them shirts is a joke. MAURICE slowly swings a bat.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Ima' whack that shit to the gate yo.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Word 'bee, these mothafuckas is soft. CONOR interrupts the major league confidence.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay, the Mau Maus are © and 2 and have only scored three runs.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yo Coach, I could pitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah Ray-Ray you pitch, we need to save Freddy for Saturday. Everybody else know where they're playin'? The KIKUYUS start to take the field. CONOR yells towards the outfield. CONOR (cont'd) Louis you're in left field. (a beat) The other left field. G-BABY stands next to CONOR waiting for his attention.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Tiki wanna come back. G-BABY motions towards the bleachers where we see TIKI sitting with a hooded sweatshirt pulled over his head. G-BABY (cont'd) But I need to regotiate his contract.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What are the terms.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Tiki wants you to tell Alonzo that Tiki's the best player, 2... only he gets pizza after each homerun he hits. 3... if he whacks it out the gate he gets a whole pizza to take home. CONOR looks at G-BABY and then at TIKI.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: When the season's over we'll vote on who's the best player. He can have the same pizza bonuses as everyone else. If he hits it over the fence I'll buy him a pizza.  G-BABY responds with his best business air.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Okay, let me discuss the regotiations with my client. G-BABY rushes to the bleachers as we cut in to....

dialogues.speaker: MAU MAUS GAME IN PROGRESS
dialogues.text: RAY-RAY doesn't throw nearly as hard as FREDDY but he does manage to throw strikes. He works his way out of a bases loaded jam with a pop up to CALVERT at first. CALVERT baskets the ball no problem. MAURICE and ALONZO take turns clearing the bases with hard hit ground balls that make their way through the outfield.

dialogues.speaker: KIKUYU DUGOUT
dialogues.text: With the sky darkening and the game well in hand CONOR relaxes against a dugout pole. TIKI approaches.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Wassup, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Tirakian, I spoke to your agent.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: I could come back?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: If you apologize to the team and you and Alonzo work it out. If the team's alright with it I'm alright with it. TIKI nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KIKUYUS again rejoice in "2-4-6-8" as the MAU MAUS went down without a fight. CONOR rounds the team up after the cheer.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Listen, Tiki and I talked and he wants to come back. I said it was up to the team, but I wanna take a vote. All in favor? EVERYONE but ALONZO raises his hand. CONOR (cont'd) Alonzo, Tiki is prepared to shake hands with you and move on. Are you willing? TIKI appears and stares down ALONZO.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Sorry Lonzo.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: We won two games with out him. The TEAM jumps an ALONZO with yells of "C'mon Man", and "Tiki's back". "Cool out Lonzo". ALONZO puts out his hand and TIKI slaps it, a truce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TICKY is smoking a cigarette, waiting for CONOR who pulls up in the stationwagon. CONOR gets out.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: It's ten to 8, what happened to 7 o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fuck you Ticky, I'm really not in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask my nuts what kind a mood they're in out here huh? It must be forty degrees. They head inside the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two guys sit in an old office with three TV's. FINK is a man in his sixties with smooth skin and a shiny bald head wreathed with white hair. ED is a younger and taller man.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: Ticky, this is Ed. TICKY is quick to shake ED's hand out of respect.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: This is Conor O'Neill, he wanted to meet you. FINK nods as he has already sized CONOR up.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: Whaddya do for money?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm a trader at Morgan Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: Bullshit. First lie. TICKY laughs to offset the uneasiness. FINK (cont'd) I don't care what you do for money. I just need to know you're gonna have it when I need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta '97 Buick out there that's worth 15 grand. FINK pauses to reassess.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: You gonna try to beat me one time? So you can pay off whoever else you owe?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I wanna make a big bet.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: How big?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: 12 grand. FINK nods in understanding.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: And...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: And if I win I wanna get paid, no pressure to keep bettin' it. FINK looks at ED.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: This guy's too serious.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fuck you. ED gets out of his chair, FINK slowly rises putting a hand in ED's direction to subdue him.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: I got a handful of clients, they lay a hundred grand a weekend. They're not emotional about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can cover it.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: You seem too emotional about this 12 grand. Desperate.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fuck you FINK looks at TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: What is it with him and the "fuck you"?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: That's his thing - he always says, "fuck you".

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Ticky, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: Don't you want your number?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You gonna take my bet?

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: Ed, what's the next number?

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: You're account 27 when you call in and your handle is....?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Kikuyus.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: What? Kikuyus?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Kikuyus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed you got it?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Kikuyus, yup. ED has logged the information in a tiny ledger.

dialogues.speaker: FINK
dialogues.text: Kikuyus. You're a strange kid. I'm interested to see what happens with you. FINK has gotten up and approached CONOR. He hands him a business card FINK (cont'd) Here's the business line. FINK sizes him up one more time, he then stares out the window. FINK (cont'd) That wagon have power seats? FINK looks to see TICKY and CONOR closing the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KIKUYUS are cruising to another victory, this time against the PYGMIES. The PYGMIES wear nice green and black uniforms. The PYGMY players appear noticeably bigger than the KIKUYUS, but they can't catch up to FREDDY's fast ball. We watch FREDDY as his high leg kick is getting more fluid and he continues to listen to the walkman attached to his belt occasionally pausing to hear the music that focuses him.

dialogues.speaker: KIKUYUS BENCH
dialogues.text: CONOR shakes his head in awe of FREDDY's prowess. He turns to G-BABY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he listen to?

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Same song over and over.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Big Poppa by Notorious B, I, G. CONOR stares blankly.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: How does it go.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: (sings) I love it when you call me big Poppa, (he waves his hands above his head) Wave your hands in the air if you’re a true player. Cause I see some ladies tonight that should be havin' my baby, baby. CONOR stares at G-BABY as if he just recited Arabic. Conor looks towards the pitcher's mound.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER'S MOUND
dialogues.text: FREDDY pauses between pitches, listens to the music and does a subtle stretch that allows him to wave his hands in the air just like G-BABY has done.

dialogues.speaker: KIKUYUS BENCH
dialogues.text: CONOR nods his head with remote understanding. FREDDY strikes out the side to end the game. The KIKUYUS crowd which has grown to almost ten, cheers  the victory. We see ELIZABETH clapping her support, CONOR is stopped by her presence. She waves to him, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KIKUYUS BENCH
dialogues.text: CONOR plays the role of COACH with new zeal.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We're 6 and 3, big game on Wednesday. Practice tomorrow 3:30. Also, you guys should continue to ask people to come to the games. Home team crowds help. Okay, let's cheer the Pygmies. 2,4,6,8- The KIKUYUS join CONOR in the requisite cheer. CONOR locks eyes with ELIZABETH who smiles wide at him. She is taken with the sight of him helping the kids. After the cheer CONOR grabs FREDDY. CONOR (cont'd) Freddy, could I borrow your tape? FREDDY pulls it out of his bag and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Coach you could have it, I got two more just in case. CONOR tousles his hair as he sees ELIZABETH standing next to him. FREDDY takes off to join his friends, ELIZABETH remains.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're really great with them. CONOR continues to lay it on thick.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: They're great kids, I feel blessed.  ELIZABETH momentarily pauses, "blessed" is pushing it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you, would you like to get a late lunch? CONOR decides to push his luck.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I always take the kids for pizza after the game. Just them and me. ALONZO overhears this lie and is about to bust him on it.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You always what?! CONOR steps in front of ALONZO and redirects the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Dinner would be better, there's a bar that's got good food on the corner of 6th and Elston... 7:00? She can't figure out if she was just scammed or not.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay 6th and Elston 7:00. CONOR smiles as he gently shoves ALONZO out of the way, preventing him from disclosing his scam.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Everyone in the car we're goin' for pizza like we always do! The KIKUYUS turn to CONOR with surprise as ELIZABETH smiles suspiciously before walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FINNEGAN's is a big step above DUFFY's but it's really just an Irish pub that's been updated to a sports bar with waitresses and food service. CONOR stands against a brass railing studying one of the 20 TV's on the wall. The TV is blasting out the Detroit Pistons - New York Knicks game. ELIZABETH enters this world for the first time. She takes in the bar to realize the only women in there are waitresses with short skirts and low cut tee shirts. Men in business suits with absent ties are drinking draft beer and studying TV's with more than a fan's interest. ELIZABETH spots CONOR and approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Conor? CONOR seems startled by her appearance as he's obviously lost in the world of basketball betting. He tries to focus.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hey, uh...let's eat. Why don't we sit... CONOR locates a tiny table in the immediate proximity that retains a bird's eye view of the game he's watching. ELIZABETH quietly accepts the strained conditions and sits opposite the preoccupied CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So, I wanted to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, I wanted to talk to you- (suddenly to the TV)

dialogues.speaker: BULLSHIT
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH is put off by CONOR's lack of concern for their date, she regrets having come.  CONOR returns to her. CONOR (cont'd) So, do you wanna drink?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What's wrong? I come here all the time with the guys I work with.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's a nice - (again to the TV)

dialogues.speaker: GOOD CALL
dialogues.text: (back to her) What were you saying?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nothing, you were about to tell me exactly what you do. CONOR senses her hostility and focuses to spin his lies.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Foreign trade.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Right, that fast paced Canadian market. CONOR calls her on her sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I know you don't work at Morgan Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a regular employee of Mr.-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Please! From the minute I laid eyes on you I knew you didn't work there and I don't care, I'm here because - CONOR can't help but check the TV. He reacts toa score...

dialogues.speaker: KNICKS BY 4, 2 MINUTES TO GO
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH gets up and walks out of the bar. CONOR finishes checking his scores before turning back to see her leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR rushes out, beer in hand, to catch ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hey! Come back here. ELIZABETH stops and faces CONOR. CONOR vents his life's frustration with the people who judge him.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why'd you come here? To bust me in the lie about where I work? You win.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I came to talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that I don't have a job and that I scalp tickets for money with a guy named Ticky who still lives with his mother.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You coach kids that I teach so we have a common interest. CONOR angrily lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I get paid under the table to coach that team. And I only do that cause I'm in a big hole with two bookies who are lookin' to kill me. CONOR studies her unflinching face.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You know all this?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I spoke to Jimmy Devlin after Calvert got beat up, he told me -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You just think I'm a joke.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: It's people like me that make people like you feel better about your tiny life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fuck me?! That's my line. Fuck you. You're ridiculous. CONOR is stunned by her toughness.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is unbelievable, I can't believe I came down here for this.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why did you come? If you know I'ma liar? You don't trust me. ELIZABETH looks him dead in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They do.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Those kids trust you and they don't trust anybody. CONOR looks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So what? I'm done with that. Shit, who cares? I gotta plan to get me out.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I just came to see what they see, because they're never wrong. CONOR starts laughing at her melodramatics.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: God you're dramatic.  CONOR mocks her by throwing his arms outstretched and spinning around. CONOR (cont'd) Take a good look... see what they see!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I came to talk to you about a job.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Well unless it pays 12 grand an hour I'm not interested. CONOR goes back in to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR stands with TICKY who is dressed in a dark suit with an overcoat eyeing each mourner who comes up the walkway.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No, I'm telling you, Freddy pitches with his walkman on! He stands on the mound listening to his walkman. CONOR laughs as he imitates FREDDY rocking to his music. CONOR (cont'd) And Tiki is a monster at the plate, a natural, I'm tellin' you.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Don't get wrapped up in this team.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Did you bone the nun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not a nun!

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Nah, that's not gonna work out.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Good, now maybe you can start tryin' to sell some tickets.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Don't yeah me, I've been carryin' you on my back the last coupla weeks. Did you miss a payment with the Barber?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah I did. I shined him this week.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: That goofy kid Gino came into Duffy's askin' for you. I'm worried about you. We're partners and I'm doin' everything. I know you're sweatin' the bookies right now but you're asleep at the wheel. A handful of GRIEVING WOMEN make their way up the steps, TICKY solemnly approaches them. TICKY (cont'd) Mrs. Calagieri, I'm sorry for your loss -- I was a friend of your husband's, I was - The YOUNGEST of the women turns to TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of us is Marie Caligieri.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: My mistake. The MOURNERS continue on. TICKY continues.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I mean we’re partners right? I'm invested in this thing with you.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I just gotta lay the 12 grand with Fink and win. If I could just win that 12 g's I'm tellin' ya I would be set. Either way I gotta quit coachin' but if I win I'm set.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Let's just get you past Fink then we'll both be set. You cover against Miami and we can really get goin' with this thing. Another group of MOURNERS makes its way up the walkway. TICKY approaches an older woman. TICKY (cont'd) Marie? Marie Caligieri? The older woman turns to TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE CALIGIERI
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry for your loss. MARIE CALIGIERI throws her arms around TICKY and wails in sorrow. TICKY hangs on uncomfortably.  TICKY (cont'd) I knew your husband for years.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE CALIGIERI
dialogues.text: He was a great man.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Yes, he was a great man. And he had great season tickets for the Bulls and the Bears.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE CALIGIERI
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Marie, his season tickets for the - MARIE smacks TICKY in the head, TICKY reels from the blow. Two other women hold MARIE back. Oblivious

dialogues.speaker: MARIE CALIGIERI
dialogues.text: He left those tickets to his nephew you low life. to MARIE's pain, TICKY expresses his own.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Shit! That screwy bastard!

dialogues.speaker: MARIE CALIGIERI
dialogues.text: What? What did you say? C'mere so I can poke you in the eye! The women pull MARIE away. TICKY faces CONOR in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I think that went well. TICKY heads towards the car, pulling off his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR locks the stationwagon and begins walking down the block towards his building. Out of instinct he looks around. The lights of a parked car go on. CONOR straightens up and begins walking with casual purpose down the street. CONOR takes out his keys and walks past his house and crosses the street. He takes a few steps up the stoop of a small apartment building and fumbles with his keys as if about to enter the building. CONOR turns to see the car idling by the curb, the BARBER'S SON gets out of the car. CONOR pretends to see him for the first time. He acts flustered as he puts his keys in his pocket and takes off sprinting down the block. The BARBER'S SON takes a few steps towards him and then yells to the car.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S SON
dialogues.text: Get him, Gino, go! GINO is the thinner of the two guys and he sets out on a dead run to catch CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY
dialogues.text: CONOR comes flying around the corner and leaps to grab the fire escape, he misses. CONOR stands below it panting, exhausted. He looks up at the lowest rung of the metal ladder that must be just under ten feet off the ground. He leaps flat footed and misses again.

dialogues.speaker: STREET OUTSIDE THE ALLEY
dialogues.text: GINO surveys the dark street for sound or movement, he approaches the alley and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR takes a few steps out of the alley and sees GINO from behind, he quietly scurries back in to the dead- end alley. CONOR has regained his breath and takes a few steps backwards. He sizes up the jump and takes two graceful steps and leaps with one hand outstretched and grabs the rung. CONOR swings silently, struggling to maintain his grip. He slowly pulls his second hand to the rung and now rests as he is firmly attached with both hands. He begins to pull himself up the ladder toward the window on the first floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the first floor hallway we see a window open and a slow breeze blowing an old yellowed curtain into the hall. CONOR's foot comes through the window first, followed gracefully with the rest of his body. Once inside he quietly closes the window and heads down the hall to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR enters the apartment and crouches to the floor without turning on the light. He crawls his way to the window and peers sideways to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see that GINO has returned to keep the BARBER'S SON company as he stakes out the small building across the street that CONOR appeared to be trying to enter. CONOR pulls himself to the wall and rests. Sweat accompanies the rise and fall of his shoulders as his breath continues to attempt to right itself.  CONOR pulls the phone to him using the phone line attached to the jack next to him on the ground. He dials.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Account 27, Kikuyus, yeah. What's the line on the Bulls tomorrow night against Miami. (he listens) Gimme twelve grand on the Bulls minus 6. Wait... We watch CONOR chew his finger in a gambler's moment of indecision. His faith waivers...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'll take Miami and the 6 points. Yeah twelve thousand. CONOR hangs up the phone and remains seated on the floor of his dark apartment, breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game day against the IBOS is met with more than normal tension as CONOR is distracted by the twelve thousand dollar bet he has riding on the Miami Heat tonight. TICKY appears behind the fence.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Conor. CONOR turns to see TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Did you play it?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Twelve grand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve grand.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: How many points are you giving?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm getting 6. TICKY stops the quick exchange to absorb this information.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You took Miami?! Are you on crack?! You got a death ish?! You laid twelve grand against the Bulls?! Oh my God this is -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Shut up Ticky! I'm under alotta pressure right now, I need you to support me! CONOR struggles with the desperate look of a gambler on his last run. TICKY sees his pain and backs off.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: MATT HYLAND is the coach of the undefeated IBOS and he strides with smug confidence to the KIKUYUS dugout.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: Coach, can I have a word. CONOR steps away from the fence and meets MATT near home plate. The UMPIRE and AL CARTER are standing in postures suggesting a summit. AL CARTER extends an official band.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Al Carter, league's commissioner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: Coach we're all concerned about the age of a few of the boys an your team.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Can you produce birth certificates for your players. CONOR sorts through the disorganized folder he carries KIKUYUS paperwork in.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: All I got is what Coach James Devlin from Morgan Stanley gave me. MATT HYLAND points out the certificates with the ease of a man who has put many coaches through this test.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: Here they are.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: What're the names of those two boys at third base.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD BASE
dialogues.text: We see MAURICE and ALONZO standing next to each other laughing at CALVERT who they keep throwing short hops to.

dialogues.speaker: HOME PLATE SUMMIT
dialogues.text: CONOR turns to the summit.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Alonzo and Maurice.  MATT HYLAND is scrutinizing a specific birth certificate, he holds it up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: Which one is Maurice?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: The kid in the grey sweats.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: This birth certificate's been altered.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: The 9 has been changed to a 3. They all huddle around the birth certificate. We see that the number has been crudely reworked.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: You gotta be born before September of '86.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Well, the kid is out of the league and the Kikuyus are on suspension. Next violation could lead to being dropped.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Look, what are you guys the gestapo?

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: What's the point of this league? To teach kids that lying is okay if you can get away with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think these kids have slightly bigger problems to deal with than forged birth certificates. CONOR has squared to MATT HYLAND suggesting a confrontation. AL CARTER sides with MATT.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: I don't know where Morgan Stanley got you from but I can tell you that if they wanna stay in this league they gotta follow the by- laws. The kid goes, now. CONOR stares in slack-jawed awe of the little league bureaucracy. He doesn't need this shit, not today.

dialogues.speaker: KIKUYUS BENCH
dialogues.text: CONOR is now pissed and distracted as he finishes announcing the line up.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: - Calvert bats 7th plays first base, Freddy pitches and bats 8th and Louis you play right field and bat 9th. The KIKUYUS begin to take the field, MAURICE appears before CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Why I ain't playin', you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Maurice the other coach-

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: Cuz I'm sorry ‘bout shovin' Ray-Ray, I just wanna play.  CONOR can't believe how difficult this is.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Listen, they know that you changed your birth certificate. I can't let you play. The quiet, stoic MAURICE begins to break down.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: But my moms said it was okay, that she would tell them if they asked that I was born earlier. She said it was okay.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: There's nothin' I can do Maurice, why don't you just sit down and watch the - MAURICE takes off running so incredibly fast that it draws the attention of everyone at the field. We watch as MAURICE disappears into the horizon of right field.

dialogues.speaker: GAME
dialogues.text: FREDDY has completed his warm-ups and the first batter steps in the box. FREDDY adjusts his head phones and sways to the music only he can hear. He fires the first pitch past a swinging IBO player. The KIKUYU infield responds with proud shouts for FREDDY's dominance. Whoosh, strike two, strike three. The ball gets tossed around the infield. MATT HYLAND and AL CARTER have reconvened behind home plate with the UMPIRE. CONOR storms out of the dugout to see what the conference is about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AL CARTER is nodding his head in agreement with MATT HYLAND who is casually pleading his case. The UMPIRE obviously sides with the guys who sign his check.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: Coach we're just in agreement that the pitcher can't wear the headphones.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Matt makes a good point about safety.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: C'mon, you're kidding me right?

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: It would be terrible for the kid to get hurt because he couldn't hear a dangerous situation.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: He's gotta lose the headphones. CONOR turns to the field and starts calling out to his players.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Bring it in you guys! Bring it in! CONOR waves the players in to a circle at home plate.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you guys to explain to them why they lost Maurice and why Freddy can't wear headphones. The KIKUYUS have gathered at home plate. CONOR (cont'd) And why the IBOS and the PYGMIES have nice uniforms and we have shitty Tee shirts.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Easy coach, you're already on a warning. CONOR turns in frustration and addresses the KIKUYUS.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: This is the commissioner and this is the coach of the goofiest team in the league and they kicked Maurice off the team because he was born two weeks late and they're makin' Freddy take his head phones off.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Fellas you understand that everyone has to follow the same rules. The KIKUYUS stand stunned at the news of MAURICE's departure. G-BABY blurts out an unclear protest.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: That some weak ass bullshit, you bitch ass mothafucking bustas. The KIKUYUS giggle, MATT HYLAND steps in and tries to intimidate G-BABY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say? G-BABY cowers a little as MATT has stepped close to him, CONOR takes another step to MATT.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I believe he said "That is some weak ass bullshit" and then he referred to you and the commissioner as "Bitch ass motherfucking bustas". MATT is shocked at CONOR's retell. CONOR (cont'd) Was that it G-Baby? G-BABY smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I agree with him -- you are a bit of a bitch ass motherfucking busta. The KIKUYUS giggle and MATT steps into CONOR's face. CONOR smiles, dying for an excuse to blow off some of his pre-bet tension. AL CARTER pulls CONOR away from

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: You are on thin ice pal, I can have you removed from this league.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: This is my last game. I quit. The KIKUYUS react with, "What?" and "What he say?" CONOR (cont'd) I'm out, I got business out of town.  AL CARTER changes course.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: Alright listen, Kikuyus back on the field. (to Freddy) Son, no head phones. Coaches back to the dugouts. MATT, AL and the UMPIRE walk away. CONOR turns to see the KIKUYUS staring at him. Their faces register the disappointment of CONOR's pending departure.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: C'mon let's go. Get out there. The KIKUYUS still stare. He loses it... CONOR (cont'd) What did you expect?! That I was gonna coach this team for the whole year?! These words fall like daggers on the already depleted spirits of the KIKUYUS. The players slowly wander back to their positions.

dialogues.speaker: GAME
dialogues.text: FREDDY is nervous and wild as he walks in two runs. The IBOS show no mercy as MATT HYLAND encourages the IBOS to taunt FREDDY. FREDDY is defenseless and his confidence is shot. FREDDY begins to aim the ball slowly. The IBOS now start to crank it all over the field. The rout is on.

dialogues.speaker: KIKUYUS BENCH
dialogues.text: CONOR talks with TICKY through the fence.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You guys suck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever, I just quit.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: I'll see ya' at the game. TICKY walks away as CONOR checks his watch. A nervous chill shoots down CONOR's spine as the bet is only a few hours away.

dialogues.speaker: GAME
dialogues.text: The IBOS scream a mean spirited rendition of the "2,4,6,8" song, quickly followed by an equally smug chant of "Who's gonna knock you out? IBOS gonna knock you out!". The KIKUYUS mill slowly through the dugout. They just got creamed by the IBOS and CONOR just quit. The players appear abandoned and humiliated. CONOR is hustling to collect the equipment, obviously needing to get out of there. CALVERT breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Next practice is Saturday right? 11:00? Someone gonna be here right? CONOR responds diplomatically.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll make sure someone's here for practice on Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yo coach you could ride us home right? CONOR stops for a second and looks into the defeated faces. He checks his watch, debates and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are on your own tonight. It's early still so go straight home. CONOR continues to pack the equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR shuffles through the scalping scene, he finds TICKY who is mid-transaction.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: 250 for the pair.

dialogues.speaker: BUYER
dialogues.text: First quarter's almost over.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Look pal I'm not emotional about this shit, you're standing here with a Miami Jersey and a dorky Dolphin hat. You got 250 or I walk and I guarantee you they won't last to that hot dog stand. The BUYER is moved by TICKY's pitch and hands over the money. CONOR admires TICKY savvy.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: That was nice, how you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Not bad, floors went for a grand, even the singles. I might eat ten mezzanine but I can live.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What's the score?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's close, they're trading baskets. I didn't save any good pairs I didn't think you'd want to -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No, I'm gonna watch through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR and TICKY stand outside the large plate glass window of a sports bar attached to the UNITED CENTER. Being outside allows them the freedom to yell and move around without hassle from the owner or patrons. CONOR paces and then looks in with TICKY to see the action.

dialogues.speaker: BIG SCREEN TV
dialogues.text: Through the glass we watch a big screen TV that shows the game to have a strange, slow quality. MIAMI, the team in black, in-bounds the ball and a guy takes a shot at the buzzer. It misses.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR AND TICKY OUTSIDE THE BAR
dialogues.text: CONOR and TICKY are frozen in their stances until the shot misses. CONOR explodes with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: SHIT! Hardaway is ice cold.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: It's alright, one quarter to go Bulls are winning by 3 points and you're gettin' six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ticky, beware the sleeping giant. You know it, you were here the night Tommy and me had won four grand on the Bear's game... but we bet the whole thing against the Bulls giving 9. TICKY reflects on the pain.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, the sleeping giant scored 21 in the fourth quarter. CONOR is white with fear as feeding on his own adrenaline has made him woozy.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don't know what I'm gonna do Ticky.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: You're gonna ride this bitch out, if you catch it we go to Duffy's and stick his nose in shit. CONOR is staring off.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: If it goes down, I gotta leave.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Where you gonna go?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Got a cousin in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Paints cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stiff Fink.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Nah, Fink gets the car, Jimmy and his company gets the "fuck you". CONOR is noticeably shaken, TICKY tries to cheer him.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: C'mon man, you're up right now, ride it out. TICKY checks the game through the glass. CONOR widens his stance for balance.

dialogues.speaker: WE DISSOLVE THROUGH THE GLASS TO LATER IN THE GAME
dialogues.text: We again watch the game through the soft haze of the plate glass window. The players appear slow but frantic, with less than 30 seconds to go, the game is tied. A tall white guy throws up a long awkward shot. TICKY's voice narrates the action.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Kukoc throws up a prayer... it's good, holy shit! Holy Shit!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Should I look? Should I look?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: NO! NO! You're not looking is working, keep not looking! We see CONOR hunched over staring at the ground, fully engaged in the betting man's lucky, "Not watching ritual".

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: How much time is left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven seconds left, Bulls by two, Miami has the ball at half court they're comin' offa' twenty second time out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh God Ticky am I outta the woods?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Miami will shoot the three to try an' win it. They're on the road that's a rule -- never go to overtime on the road. If they make it you win, if they miss it you win. CONOR yells at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What's happening?! A FAMILY walks past slowing slightly to observe CONOR who appears rabid as he continues to scream and plead with the ground while pacing in circles. CONOR (cont'd) Talk to me, what's happening?! Oh God never again Ticky, NEVER AGAIN! The FAMILY rushes off as TICKY begins to narrate.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Mashburn is taking the ball from the ref... inbounds to Brown... they're trying to foul him he passes to Hardaway. CONOR can't resist, he jumps up and presses his face to the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardaway jumps behind the three point arc... shoots... it's.. OFF! He missed!... Mourning tips it... it's good!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Mourning tipped it in off the glass with no time left.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Tied up? Tied up?! TICKY has fallen silent, he breathes heavy trying to regulate his heart as he utters the fatal words...

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Overtime.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Overtime, I'm fucked. CONOR rests his burning forehead against the cool glass of the window. He closes his eyes trying to accept the 5 minutes of prolonged torture...

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: CONOR leans his back against the glass as TICKY narrates in a solemn voice.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Uhm, Miami has the ball with 24 seconds down by 8, wait Pippen steals, fouled. Shooting two.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do Tick?  TICKY avoids the question by continuing to narrate the game. Like a death sentence read by a judge he drones on.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Pippen hits the second, Hulls by 10. 15 seconds left. CONOR begins to lose it, the reality of his situation coupled with his crashing adrenaline causes a rush of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: My God Ticky, I was down 11 grand before I made this bet.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Hardaway drives untouched, lay up. Hulls by 8.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: When this bet misses I'm down over 24 grand with the vig. CONOR turns away as his emotions start to get the best of him. CONOR begins to slide down the wall of glass, he sits on the ground. TICKY continues in monotone. TICKY (cont'd) Bulls with the ball 9 seconds left they pass around the trap, long pass... Ope picked off... TICKY's hand grabs CONOR's shoulder for unity. He pulls him up.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Hardaway at half court... CONOR and TICKY both lean into the glass watching the last shot.

dialogues.speaker: BIG SCREEN TV
dialogues.text: We see the final shot floating through the air with incredible arc, nearly straight up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch them frozen against the glass, we await an outburst telling the result.

dialogues.speaker: IT'S GOOD
dialogues.text: TICKY screams and yells and runs around in circles, CONOR studies the screen trying to find the score.

dialogues.speaker: BABY
dialogues.text: CONOR shoots his arms up in a "V" as if he just floored the champ. TICKY embraces CONOR and lifts him as if he were his corner man. They circle the asphalt outside the window triumphant for once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mellow Thursday night crowd is disturbed by the raucous entry of CONOR and TICKY who are well on their way to a "fall down drunk".

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (drunkenly sings) I love it when you call me big Pa-Pa wave your hands in the air- CONOR looks at TICKY who shoots his hands above his head. CONOR (cont'd) If you's a true playa'...' cause I see some ladies tonight that should be havin' my baby...  TICKY (sings) Baby! TICKY and CONOR continue to sing and dance. DUFFY comes out of his office with a "Racing Form" in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You should take this party somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Kiss our ass Duffy, he beat Fink tonight for twelve grand. CONOR smiles in triumph.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You got my 6 grand?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Put in this tape. TICKY hands a tape over the bar, PETER the bartender accepts it. With a nod from DUFFY, PETER puts it in. The NOTORIOUS B.I.G.'s Big Poppa starts pumping out of the stereo. The few patrons look up trying to figure out if they're still in the same bar. TICKY downs a shot while dancing. CONOR has retired to a seat at the bar. DUFFY stands on the other side studying him.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: So you beat Fink for 12 large?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. TICKY jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean you don't know? We're rollin' it on the Bulls Saturday night. CONOR looks to DUFFY for his approval about letting his money ride.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Let me know, I'll take that action on Ticky's number if you wanna play it.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: We'll bet it with Fink. Bulls didn't cover tonight, they got Vancouver on Saturday, they'll cover. 24 grand.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, 24 grand. DUFFY stops the tape. He studies CONOR before pushing his buttons.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Then what? You think you won the game of life? What next? Huh? CONOR stands drunk, unsteady. He stares at DUFFY who just asked CONOR the question he has no answer for.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: If you win that? Whaddya' gonna do with your life? (laughing) Coach little league baseball for black kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I DON'T KNOW!... I dunno Duffy, maybe I'm just a loser right? Not like you Mister Big Time huh? I'm just a loser.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Get ‘outta here you're startin' to sound like your father. CONOR lunges across the bar, TICKY and the bartender grab CONOR and pull him towards the door...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So what?! I am my father! He gambled, lost it all -

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Go home-

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Gambled away his family. I got nobody to lose Duffy! Nobody to gamble away! The whole bar is looking at him now. CONOR has calmed and now stands by the door about to leave. CONOR (cont'd) You tell me Duffy, what am I supposed to do? Huh? what would my dad do?!

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Okay, O'Neill, bring me my money tomorrow. Night night, time for beddy bye. The BARFLIES giggle. CONOR turns in the doorway and steps back towards the bar as something doesn't sit right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk down to me, maybe I will coach baseball, MAYBE

dialogues.speaker: SHIT
dialogues.text: TICKY pulls CONOR outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TICKY is holding CONOR who is still trying to fight his way back into the bar. CONOR is beginning to break down as his drunkenness has mixed strangely with his adrenaline crash. He stops fighting and stares at TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don't know why, but coaching was the best thing I ever did. It made me feel good. TICKY tries to put an arm around CONOR. CONOR shoves him away and stumbles into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR stares out the window of his apartment listening to a local sports radio show naming the pitching match-ups for Major League Baseball games around the league.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: Mets are at Houston, I love all these non-division games. It's gonna be a beautiful day at Wrigley today, I dunno about beautiful for the cubbies, Maddux back to the scene of the crime against Wood? Forget it, anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: them. stack

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: door.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: there picks up two stacks of bills and thumbs through A knock at the door causes CONOR to slip one in his pocket and another under the radio. grabs the bat and stands to the side of the

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: It's Ticky? doesn't respond. TICKY (cont'd) I'm alone, I promise. I'll take off my crusty underwear and stand naked in your hallway to prove it. still doesn't move. TICKY (cont'd) Fine I'm gonna lay on the ground and slide my nuts under your door until you let me in. opens the door with bat in hand. TICKY stands alone. CONOR moves to let him in.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I paid Duffy, we're square. TICKY (cont'd) Did you call Fink? Are we down on the Bulls? How many points are we givin'?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Fink wants to see that I still have his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great let's go by there and flash 'em some cabbage and bet the 12 grand like we said. CONOR is quiet and TICKY senses something... TICKY (cont'd) What's with you, we’re gonna do this right?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay... I just gotta go by the field in Cabrini.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ I thought you quit? CONOR snaps.

dialogues.speaker: QUIT
dialogues.text: (composes himself) I gotta drop the equipment off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR continues to listen to the radio. A Cubs pre- game show hypes the match-ups between the hall-of- famer Greg Maddux and rookie phenom Carey Woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stationwagon pulls up behind the Backstop and we can see that the KIKUYUS are arriving for practice. CONOR jumps out of the car and grabs the equipment bag and runs to the dugout for a quick drop off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KIKUYUS gather around CONOR as he starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: You here to tell us you quit?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: That's old news. CONOR surveys their faces, all are emotionless except G-BABY who can't help but smile, happy to see CONOR. CONOR explains.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I left a message for Coach Jimmy that I was just gonna drop off the equipment today, he should be here any minute. The KIKUYUS stare at him, they know JIMMY will never show. No one will. CONOR can no longer look them in the face. The car horn blasts.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: TICKY is standing outside the car smoking a cigarette. He continues to reach through the window, sounding the horn in frustration. CONOR starts walking back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: Yeah, keep goin', sucka'!

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: Yeah, we goin' to the ship by ourself!

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: CONOR returns to the car and looks at TICKY.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I can't bet the 12 grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, I understand. We should just bet 6 grand and wait till -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No, I can't. Off camera we hear ALONZO yell...

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Get your bummy ass outta here! We a betta team with out you anyway! CONOR storms back to the KIKUYUS. The players are a little scared of CONOR's energy.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: HAH! I'm not even listening to you... So go ‘head, good luck on your own. Call me when you get to the "ship" without me. CONOR storms away again. The KIKUYUS exchange looks of confusion as CONOR continues to argue with himself. CONOR (cont'd) I'm so glad I'm done with this. So, good luck... HAH! See you later. CONOR again reaches his car.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Can we please go, if Fink think's we're comin' we should at least stop by, if we don't wanna bet it we don't... TICKY realizes he's talking to himself as CONOR has stormed back towards the players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR again stands angry before the KIKUYUS.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: How many you guys ever been to Wrigley field to see the Cubs play? The KIKUYUS don't move, an admission that none of them has. CONOR (cont'd) HAH! That's what I thought! You guys will never be a team until you see it played right! CONOR picks up the equipment bag and walks back to the car in disgust. The KIKUYUS watch in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: CONOR returns to the car and TICKY makes a soft plea.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: Listen, you're stressed out. Let's grab a bite, we can call Fink and lay the bet.

dialogues.speaker: I'M OUT
dialogues.text: We see in CONOR the exhausted relief of a man who just exorcised a demon. He softly adds...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'm done. I'm done with all that. TICKY is silent a moment before continuing with his quest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then you gotta call Fink for me, you can't just dissolve a partnership like that I mean - CONOR yells to the KIKUYUS... CONOR (cont'd) Let's go! Get in the car, the game starts in 20 minutes. The kids rush the wagon pushing TICKY out of the way as LOUIS and FREDDY jump in the front seat. The rest of the kids dive in all the other doors and through the large window at the rear. CONOR has the car started and is backing up as TICKY runs along side.

dialogues.speaker: TICKY
dialogues.text: This is against everything that's right. CONOR zooms away, the car packed with screaming KIKUYUS. TICKY shakes his head and waves his arms pissed off for the minute it takes him to realize he's not in Kansas anymore. He looks nervously around before trying to figure his safest route home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stadium is swarming with fans trying to get in. CONOR has the kids in a tight circle, he counts heads as he approaches the mayhem. CONOR makes eye contact with a YOUNG SCALPER.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SCALPER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: 12 seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleachers? Upper deck?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Field boxes over the Cubs dugout.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SCALPER
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yeah that's possible, even if they existed that would cost 1500.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I'll give you $1200. CONOR flashes a stack of bills from his pocket. The YOUNG SCALPER sets off into the crowd. The KIKUYUS are remarkably well behaved as they all stare in awe at the beautiful old ball park.

dialogues.speaker: G-BABY
dialogues.text: It looks small from the train, but up close it's big. We see Wrigley from a low angle, the eyes of a child. The ball park is gorgeous. THE YOUNG SCALPER returns with a triumphant smile and shows CONOR a stack of tickets. CONOR examines them like a pro and hands the YOUNG SCALPER a fold of bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR escorts the KIKUYUS through the inside ramps of Wrigley. The boys move slowly, their senses are overloaded with new sounds and sights. They hand their tickets to a young stern USHER with a suit jacket who examines them and then the tickets. He shakes his head... unhooks a rope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right this way gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: We see the dream like green of the playing field that dances like magic in the minds of the boys seeing it for the first time. CONOR is stopped in his tracks. The majesty of the color and precision of the beautiful landscape reminds him that you never get used to the brilliance of a major league field.

dialogues.speaker: BOX SEATS
dialogues.text: The USHER leads the KIKUYUS to the three boxes that border the Cubs' dugout. The kids respectfully take their seats, still awed by the experience. ALONZO points to a guy picking up a bat a few feet from them.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Check it out, it's Sammy Sosa yo. The KIKUYUS all rush to that corner of the dugout and begin trying to get the player's attention. They all cali, "Hey Sammy" and "Sosa over here!". We see that the back of the players jersey reads BB denoting "bat boy", but the KIKUYUS remain clueless. Except for CALVERT...

dialogues.speaker: CALVERT
dialogues.text: That ain't Sosa. The KIKUYUS jump on CALVERT, yelling at him to "shut up", "It's Sosa!". CALVERT walks away from that corner of the dugout. Suddenly we see CALVERT's eyes go wide... SAMMY SOSA is standing right in front of him talking with the batting coach. CALVERT's mouth goes immediately dry and speech is impossible. SAMMY SOSA sees CALVERT who musters a small wave. SAMMY smiles and waves back as he continues talking with the batting coach. The rest of the KIKUYUS now see SAMMY and crowd near CALVERT's seat. They call  out, "Sammy whassup'" and they shake clenched fists at him. SAMMY smiles and approaches the KIKUYUS. He offers his clenched fist and exchanges "pounds" with the kids who in this moment have died and gone to heaven. CONOR smiles bigger than we've ever seen as he watches the boys interact with Chicago's greatest slugger.

dialogues.speaker: CUBS GAME
dialogues.text: The boys eat and spill ice cream, soda and hot dogs as they continually leave their seats to cheer the Cubs who are having an uncharacteristically offensive day against MADDUX. We watch them sing "Take me out to the Ball game" during the seventh inning stretch. CONOR joins in the somewhat hokey but cool tradition. The game ends and fans fill the aisles to go home. Never wanting to leave, the boys hang over the dugout and call out to their favorite players of the day. CONOR sits by himself staring into center field wearing a truly satisfied smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR waves to SISTER MOLINA as he passes her office an route to ELIZABETH's class. The kids have long since gone home and CONOR again finds himself outside ELIZABETH's closed door. He knocks and then waits for a response. CONOR suddenly remembers something and jumps out of the way just as the door swings open. ELIZABETH stands in the door way.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Missed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor O'Neill.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I wanted to apologize for the other night, I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I heard about the Cubs game.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how much that meant to them? CONOR quietly accepts the praise, then...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I was thinking about how you knew before dinner the other night that I didn't really work with Jimmy and them and that I had a big gambling debt and... If you were there to offer me a job... it might still stand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're not here to ask me out again? CONOR tries to read her, he guesses.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Uh... no?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Am I s'posed to be?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We need a physical activities coordinator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (she laughs) No, the school. Someone to organize games, sports, supervise recess we'd love to get a guy because -

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I think you like me.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I just got this gut feeling when you laughed before -- you were looking right at me. They stare at each other, ELIZABETH offers...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are you interested?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: In the job? ELIZABETH breaks the stare by laughing, CONOR starts laughing too.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What are we talking about here?! I'm interested, I'm interested in anything I'm supposed to be interested in. They both laugh as we see them in a long shot from down the hallway. The sun threatens its early departure as the long shadows of early spring cast a hopeful light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fresh energy surrounds the KIKUYUS as news of their trip to Wrigley has spread through the league. The boys are warming up for a game against the BAKONGOS as CONOR is approached by AL CARTER and MATT HYLAND.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Afternoon gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTEER
dialogues.text: I heard you took your team to a Cubs game.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: I didn't see any paperwork signatures of consent from the parents or-

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: It was a spur of the moment thing.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: I thought you were quitting.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I decided coaching was more important.

dialogues.speaker: AL CARTER
dialogues.text: I could toss you out, you're on a suspension. But I guess you only got two games left.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Three, counting the Championship.

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: You'd have to win both games to make the championship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can beat these guys. AL CARTER and MATT HYLAND exchange smirks of disbelief. MATT offers...

dialogues.speaker: MATT HYLAND
dialogues.text: Even if you find a way to win today, you gotta play us again Saturday, we're undefeated.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, and after we beat you we play for the championship. CONOR walks away.

dialogues.speaker: BAKONGOS GAME
dialogues.text: Emotions run high on both sides as the game is incredibly close. The BAKONGOS COACH argues a call at home place. CONOR yells at the infield ump for missing a call at first base.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The stands behind the KIKUYUS are almost full with about thirty fans. The KIKUYUS' fans are invested in every play of this game, the tension continues to build.

dialogues.speaker: DUGOUT
dialogues.text: CONOR addresses the boys who seem tired and drained from the high intensity this game has assumed.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay this is it, last licks, we're down 9 to 8. We've got Alonzo -  We see ALONZO holding a bat with his game face on.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Ray-Ray- RAY-RAY who kisses the gold cross around his neck before looking to the heavens for support.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Freddy - FREDDY smiles, lost in the world of his walkman.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: After that is Louis, Tiki and Calvert - We find CALVERT furiously sucking on his inhaler. CALVERT raises his arm as a sign of "I'm okay".

dialogues.speaker: GAME
dialogues.text: The BAKONGO pitcher fires a third strike past ALONZO, one out. RAY-RAY takes four straight pitches for a walk. CONOR grabs FREDDY.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Don't swing until you look over here and I nod "yes". Okay? FREDDY takes four straight pitches, he goes to first sending RAY-RAY to second. LOUIS approaches CONOR and awaits his orders. CONOR (cont'd) Don't swing until you look over here and I nod "yes". Okay? LOUIS watches two balls go by, he looks to CONOR who shakes his head "No".  LOUIS watches two strikes go by and looks to CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Obviously struggles but shakes his head "No". LOUIS takes ball three, full count. He again looks to CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Takes a moment before shaking his head "No." LOUIS waits for the pitch, he let's it go... BALL FOUR. Bases loaded and TIKI steps to CONOR.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Don't swing until you look over here and I nod "yes". Okay? TIKI stares at CONOR and then out towards the loaded bases. CONOR nervously shakes TIKI. CONOR (cont'd) Tiki, did you hear me? TIKI gives a halfhearted nod as he steps to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: TIKI
dialogues.text: TIKI watches two balls go by, checking with CONOR each time. Both times CONOR shakes, "No" to TIKI's dismay. At 2 and © TIKI looks to CONOR who shakes "No". TIKI awaits the next pitch and swings hitting a feeble pop up right to the pitcher who catches it making the second out. TIKI returns to the dugout as CONOR stares at him with disgust for his disrespect. CONOR tries to go on.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay, two down who's up? CONOR looks to the bench to see CALVERT attached to his inhaler looking exhausted but stable. CALVERT's mom rubs his shoulders from over the short fence separating the players from the stands. CALVERT  shakes his head "No" in an effort to communicate his inability to bat. CONOR looks down the bench to see his only sub, G-BABY staring at him. CONOR (cont'd) G-Baby you're up. G-BABY fearlessly grabs a bat and a helmet and is running toward home plate as CONOR goes to the ump to announce the substitution.

dialogues.speaker: HOME PLATE
